gengjh
2016-04-08 00:13
has joined #ci-pipeline

dileban
2016-04-08 00:30
Here are a few additional thoughts: 1. Perhaps changing the name of this channel to devops-pipeline 2. Figure out a good process for release management - Frequent minor releases, with effective use of git tags to make it easier to provide stable releases to the community. - Use conventions such as 'RC's to tag progress appropriately. 3. Build, tag and push docker images to an appropriate registry service. - Maintain a clear correspondence between git tags and docker image tags 4. Deployment methods we'd like to support: - Docker compose - Ansible/chef scripts 5. Automated testing - Which cloud service do we use? - Integration test strategies for the network - What else should we cover beyond what we already do today?

gengjh
2016-04-08 15:30
I think the good reference of the CI/CD process and release management is OpenStack, they are using gerrit, jenkins, launchpad, zuul(pipeline management to manage jenkins build and code merge), jenkins job builder and etc as I know which are very professional.

nathonline
2016-04-17 18:07

cbf
2016-04-17 20:01
I played around with hubot this weekend, and have developed something that we could use to integrate slack and github (in addition to the github plugin that Slack provides out of the box). I used http://bluemix.net to deploy the bot. It needs a Slack API token, a Github API token and we’ll probably want to get a Bluemix account to deploy this and any other bots unless we want to establish something that LF hosts (but then we have a bit more work to do to set up HA and fail-over, etc. that Bluemix (Cloud Foundry) provides out of the box. I will inquire about getting a pro bono account. I’ll also put together complete deploy instructions.

gpartha
2016-04-26 06:53
has joined #ci-pipeline

cbf
2016-04-27 23:21
so, never really documented the call we had 4/21 following the TSC call…

cbf
2016-04-27 23:22
It is pretty clear that we should transition to using Gerritt to manage reviews and Jenkins for CI

cbf
2016-04-27 23:22
this has broader implications as transitioning to Gerritt in particular will mean the following:

cbf
2016-04-27 23:23
1. we’ll lose commit history because the approach that LF requires is that we squash all past commits and make a single PR with a DCO signoff so that we can manage the DCO with certainty

cbf
2016-04-27 23:24
1a. LF has Gerrit check bot for the DCO (probably way better than mine)

cbf
2016-04-27 23:26
2. by adopting Gerritt we will have to turn all commits to Github repos to Gerritt, meaning that only Gerritt has write access. this implies that we will need to adopt a bug tracking alternative to Github. LF can support both Jira and Bugzilla… the consensus on the call was Jira seemed to be preferred option

cbf
2016-04-27 23:27
2a. there’s an automated migration from github to Jira issues, so that won’t be too much trouble

cbf
2016-04-27 23:28
3. LF made strong recommendation for Jenkins for CI.

cbf
2016-04-27 23:28
3a. they offer 24x7 support and manage themselves, whereas TravisCI is free and no support to speak of… who ya gonna call?

cbf
2016-04-27 23:29
3b. Sawtooth Lake already uses jenkins for CI so someone needs to adapt… better than supporting two modes

cbf
2016-04-27 23:29
3c. we really want (well, I do) a consistent set of tooling for Hyperledger projects

cbf
2016-04-27 23:30
3d. I think Jenkins is the right answer, so we will need to investigate migrating the TravisCI to Jenkins… This might be a good experiment for the hackathon

cbf
2016-04-27 23:32
4. we really should have formal RI function - LF can provide a resource, and we can have community members collaborating as well - I tend to agree as it seems that we’ll need to coordinate multiple repositories as we start breaking the project down to composable parts (despite my desire for a single repo build model)

cbf
2016-04-27 23:33
so, thanks again to the LF team for their deep insights

cbf
2016-04-27 23:33
: ^^

gengjh
2016-04-28 01:07
@cbf: thanks for your update

georglink
2016-04-28 13:20
I want to add to @cbf 's summary: Keeping the Wiki at GitHub or moving it to DocuWiki or MediaWiki (or Confluence) was discussed. @cbf suggested keeping the wiki at GitHub. What we didn't know is whether the wiki remains available when the repository is locked down after moving to Gerritt.

georglink
2016-04-28 13:21
Andrew suggested moving the wiki somewhere that is linked to Gerritt

georglink
2016-04-28 13:25
Also, the use of Nexus was brought up to manage binaries, move them between Jenkins jobs, and store releases.

cbf
2016-04-28 13:27
the Wiki we are using is currently the hyperledger/hyperledger repo’s wiki, though I think that someone started using the fabric wiki

cbf
2016-04-28 13:29
but thanks, @georglink for reminding me of that

cbf
2016-04-28 13:30
maybe someone could research whether the wiki is also locked down on a gerritt managed repo?

georglink
2016-04-28 13:48
If I understood it correctly, the GitHub repo would not be managed by Gerritt as it has its own repo that has a different logic from GitHub. Instead, the Gerritt repo can be duplicated to GitHub periodically to have an outfacing publicly available copy, containing a description of where to find instructions for contributing on Gerritt.

georglink
2016-04-28 13:48
A difference that needed elaboration during the call was GitHub's pull request vs. Gerritt's change request. - For anyone not on the call: the idea was to provide a tutorial and maybe a 1h walk through before making the switch.

cbf
2016-04-28 15:29
correct, we definitely want to have a Gerritt 101 session for Gerritt n00bs

georglink
2016-04-28 15:37
@cbf, I not sure you saw Dan Middleton's comment in the chat during the call, since he left before you reported on the tooling and could not reply to your question: 10:20 AM - Dan Middleton: oh on tools github is better than gerrit for us. Also we have existing jenkins material for CI.

cbf
2016-04-28 15:37
oh, I didn’t hear that on the call with LF last week… I’ll connect with him

cbf
2016-04-28 15:37
thanks for catching that

cbf
2016-04-28 15:38
I didn’t see it in the chat

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-05-24 21:02
@bcbrock: I am not 100%, but I think if the jenkins setup itself is reasonably locked down, you can have a worker that isnt just open to the public

ry
2016-05-24 21:02
bcbrock: we usually set up a VPN to keep this stuff off the internet.

ghaskins
2016-05-24 21:02
e.g. you can privately federate them with the security equal to the security of the overall jenkins config

cbf
2016-05-24 21:05
if we could get an openpower box made available via softlayer or one of our partners, that would be good

ry
2016-05-24 21:08
for instance, we have builders at Azure that are only on the 10. network behind our VPN, which only allows traffic from our management network. I’m sure we can do something similar at where ever we end up with these resources, provided we can run a fairly stock Fedora VM with like 1 or 2 cores and maybe a gig of ram. The VPN box doesn’t require much.

ry
2016-05-24 21:09
by we I mean AllSeen Alliance, this other community project I work on for Linux Foundation.

bcbrock
2016-05-24 21:11
@bsmita I’m thinking SuperVessel

bcbrock
2016-05-24 21:12
This is an OpenPOWER cloud set up by IBM Research China

cbf
2016-05-24 21:34
@bcbrock: won’t that introduce networking latencies that might tend to result in failures?

cbf
2016-05-24 21:35
I thought that we also had some openpower boxen at some uni in the US… maybe Portland?

ry
2016-05-24 21:43
China has been problematic for us (LF) in the past. If we’re going to do something in China it would probably need to be self-contained

ry
2016-05-24 21:44
LF has a close relationship with OSU, if that helps.

bramwelt
2016-05-24 21:44
@cbf: Previous OSUOSL'er here. I can confirm you have resources at OSU. :wink:

dan.mccarty
2016-05-24 21:45

vpaprots
2016-05-24 21:54
has joined #ci-pipeline

cbf
2016-05-24 21:57
@dan.mccarty: wouldn't that be your team?

dan.mccarty
2016-05-24 21:58

bcbrock
2016-05-24 22:03
@ry What is the opposite of self-contained? How does non-self-contained work?

bcbrock
2016-05-24 22:04
I’never set up or really used any of these systems

bramwelt
2016-05-24 22:04
@bcbrock: Zero access to our network.

bramwelt
2016-05-24 22:05
(for self-contained)

ry
2016-05-24 22:12
bcbrock: we set up a VPN that all of the infra is on. the public facing infra (gerrit, jenkins) have a public interface and one on the private network.

ry
2016-05-24 22:12
we keep everything segregated east-west, so compromising one machine on one project doesn’t get you any closer to compromising other machines of the same type on other projects

ry
2016-05-24 22:14
north-south, within a CP, there is still a fair amount of containment. specific ports to and from specific classes of machines, etc

bcbrock
2016-05-24 22:15
OK, the POWER team is meeting tomorrow, we’ll discuss these requirements

ry
2016-05-24 22:15
CP: collaborative project. http://collabprojects.linuxfoundation.org/ for a list

ry
2016-05-24 22:15
If I start fogging you out with internal LF jargon please tell me to knock it off

cbf
2016-05-24 22:51
@bcbrock: thanks

ry
2016-05-24 23:46

ry
2016-05-24 23:47

ry
2016-05-24 23:47
read sections 1a and 1b. 1[cd] are not germane

bramwelt
2016-05-25 23:38

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:38
@bramwelt: right now, x86 is based on 14.04 and z is based on 16.04

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:39
I am interested in moving to 16.04 across the board, but we need to qualify it first

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:39
I am not against trying to qualify it sooner rather than later if it is easier on your side to target 16.04

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:40
(the fact that z seems to work on 16.04 is a good sign, but still requires some testing before we can sign off on it)

bramwelt
2016-05-26 00:40
I'd opt for the path of least resistance, so 14.04.

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:40
ok, as long as you don’t mind working through an eventual upgrade

ghaskins
2016-05-26 00:41
targetting 14.04 puts less pressure on me for the short term, so thats a positive

bramwelt
2016-05-26 00:41

bramwelt
2016-05-26 00:42

ramesh

ramesh
2016-05-26 01:27

ry
2016-05-26 01:27
vpaprots: what we’re building are vagrant setups to create and destroy builders on demand. how hard is it to set up (if even possible) z on an x64 intel vm?

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:29
hmm.. well.. depends how faithfully you want to emulate... I believe my rhel is a KVM instance? there are apis to create/destroy those over rest for that cloud from what I heard.. seems a bit heavy handed, but does guarantee that you start with an identical setup every time...

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:30
I was on a call with the LinuxONE admins day before yesterday.. they were asking if I would like a 'blockchain' image people can create instances out of...

ry
2016-05-26 01:30
we do let them live 30 minutes, I think, in case another build comes along

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:33
if I were to do it.. I would just keep the machine up, running the jenkins slave.. the trick is making sure jobs clean up after themselves (or each job starts by cleaning up if need be)

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:33
I think thats what they do to build node.js and golang.. google got three linuxone's to dispatch their ci to

ry
2016-05-26 01:35
I will defer to tykeal for the “why dispose every time”. I suspect it’s also to defray costs, in addition to cleaning up. We were talking about another project today with matrix builds that can spawn an amazing number of builds per update

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:35
hmm.. concurrent builds.. that would be 'interesting'

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:37
oh.. wait, I missed part of your question 'z on an x64 intel vm'

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:38
well.. if you really wanted, there is zpdt. its an emulator...

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:38
it is a completely different instruction set.. so you would be shooting yourself in the foot

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:38
we dispose of VMs after they idle for 30 minutes to defray costs

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:38
keeping a slave that isn't in use online all the time costs a lot of money

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:40
particularly since all the cloud providers bill by the hour

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:40
and yes, if the build doesn't need to be serialized (say merge jobs) then making sure the build is flagged for concurrent is something that should be done

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:40
cost of using LinuxONE is really beyond my paygrade, but we are already doing it for golang and nodejs, so there is certain precedent

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:41
hey, I'm not talking about anything z related here, just the basic x64 cloud instances ;)

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:41
:slightly_smiling_face:

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:42
heh.. I am saying chances are we will foot the bill for linuxone, just making sure if we do, that jenkins will dispatch there too

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:44
yes, I, ry and bramwelt were mentioning something about that. As I haven't worked with that infrastructure before I don't know specifically what's involved. In particular, if it's possible to spawn / drop "instances" easily with a Jenkins plugin or if it's going to have to be static slaves

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:44
all my cloud work has been in OpenStack, GCE, AWS and in my distant past VMWare

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:45
those are all pretty well known quantities to me on dynamic builders with Jenkins

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:45
its really just kvm running rhel

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:45
libvirt?

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:46

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:46
if it's libvirt based there's a slave cloud plugin that can work with those already

2016-05-26 01:46

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:47

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:51
once we actually start using the jenkins system we'll be able to easily scale out the number of systems in play at time. We've got one project currently at full capacity is utilizing ~1.25 T of RAM and between 1500 and 2000 CPU core

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:52
across a max of 250 instances

vpaprots

2016-05-26 01:53

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:54
which was just me bootstrapping a basic vagrant for ry and bramwelt to start working with ;)

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:55
@tykeal: z is like arm, a different processor, with its own instructions... subtle differences sometimes really give us hard times. often somebody making x assumptions without realizing they are x specific.. but then, the higher level library you use the less you care

tykeal
2016-05-26 01:55
I'm just pointing out what we've historically done

vpaprots
2016-05-26 01:55

dan.mccarty
2016-05-31 20:46

2016-05-31 20:56
dan.mccarty: Is this a static (always on) server?

dan.mccarty
2016-06-01 13:53

cbf
2016-06-01 13:55

cbf
2016-06-01 13:55

2016-06-01 13:57

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:08

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:09

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:15

Since Dan is our build guy, I propose we hijack his image :slightly_smiling_face: I will work with Dan offline about removing the restrictions, but yes, nothing should stop us today from using his system to try out jenkins on z!

cbf
2016-06-01 14:17

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:17

cbf
2016-06-01 14:18

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:18

bramwelt
2016-06-01 14:23
@bramwelt uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/bramwelt/F1D9NS9RU/-.txt and commented: @dan.mccarty: This should be all that's needed to connect Jenkins to the Z system.

bramwelt
2016-06-01 14:24
Then to connect Jenkins all we should need is a public ip or hostname.

dan.mccarty
2016-06-01 14:26
Will you need a userid and password as well as hostname/IP?

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:27
we need a hostname/IP as well as a jenkins user created as that snippet shows

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:27
though that docker group may not be needed if there's no docker on the z image

bramwelt
2016-06-01 14:29
@dan.mccarty: We shouldn't, since we have you to ping for installing deps, etc. :wink:

dan.mccarty
2016-06-01 14:29
ok.

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:33
the setup script that I wrote, installs all the dependencies, including docker... since I was being lazy, I did everything as root.. not a completely insane idea, since that was 'single user' VM..

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:34
still.. something that is 'fixable'.. dependency installation will still need privileges though.. I was wondering about that part of the build

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:35
do you expect the build machine to have all the dependencies installed? or does the build do it (i.e. within a fresh vagrant?)

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:36
we use vagrant to create build an image and then snapshot it. The dynamic builders (slaves) are then booted from that snapshot

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:36
we don't boot directly using vagrant in the build environment

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:36
it's just being used as an image creation platform

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:37
hmm.. interesting.. I was having a debate with the sysadmins the value of creating a 'snapshot' of a hyperledger image that people can then create vm's out of

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:37
it is a kvm after all...

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:37
we use the upstream cloud images as our base boot

vpaprots
2016-06-01 14:38
'upstream cloud images'.. sorry, will need a translation :slightly_smiling_face:

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:38
essentially we're using vagrant similar to the design goals of packer, except we need to actually boot the system to do the creation, which is why we use vagrant instead of packer

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:39
ubuntu cloud images: https://cloud-images.ubuntu.com/ centos cloud images: http://cloud.centos.org/centos/7/images/

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:39
the appropriate base image is loaded into our OpenStack environment. We then use that as the base image that we boot vagrant on top of and configure

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:40
The basic process is documented here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=vagrant;h=c3eb6c2c8179b20d295ca8d7d846d722daeca49c;hb=HEAD

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:42
that process produces our snapshots. We then hook them into Jenkins using the OpenStack Cloud provider plugin. With a UserData script that clones the ci-management project and executes the init_system.sh found here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=tree;f=jenkins-scripts;h=68f5408d7b690f789224e38f2777d76d4a313ec2;hb=HEAD

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:43
between the snapshot and the init script we have fully working slaves

tykeal
2016-06-01 14:43
that are easy to update

dan.mccarty
2016-06-01 14:45
The ip address is 148.100.107.97

dan.mccarty
2016-06-01 14:46
The SHOULD be good to go. :grinning: jenkins is created along with .ssh directory and key file, docker group, and /var/hyperledger

bramwelt
2016-06-01 15:02
Hmm, can't seem to connect.

bramwelt
2016-06-01 15:03
Seems that SSH is running, and I can talk to it.

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:50
@tykeal: I was curious about your statement "we need to actually boot the system to do the creation, which is why we use vagrant instead of packer"

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:51
It seems to me that both native Vagrantfile and packer methods for producing vagrant images boot a system

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:51
can you elaborate on where the limitation was that you found?

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:51
(thats not a criticism, I am just intellectually curious)

tykeal
2016-06-01 15:57
ghaskins: I'll admit something before I continue too much further with this discussion. When we were first evaluating how best to create images I didn't know about packer. Second, I haven't looked that far into it since discovering it since Vagrant works for all of our use cases and has provider plugins for all the different clouds where we use this design. When I last looked at packer it didn't have provider plugins for rackspace, libvirt or openstack. That could well have changed

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:58
ah, i see

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:59
in terms of booting a system, I think they are similar

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:59
in terms of backend support, you are probably right about that

tykeal
2016-06-01 15:59
the rackspace and openstack providers are most critical to our use cases

ghaskins
2016-06-01 15:59
it makes the most sense to use packer if you want to support more than one basic type of image

ghaskins
2016-06-01 16:00
but if you can achieve that in other ways (such as within a Vagrantfile) it might be easier to just use native facilities

tykeal
2016-06-01 16:02
ghaskins: if you look at the Vagrantfile in use for hyperledger you'll see it's actually pretty basic. Yes, it does some OpenStack specific configuration, but it wouldn't be hard to add in provider bits for libvirt or virtualbox backends for extra configuration related to those VM systems. outside of that it's, just calling configuration scripts and then 'resealing' the system so that a snapshot can be taken

ghaskins
2016-06-01 16:03
cool, sounds reasonable

tykeal
2016-06-01 16:04
@tykeal notes that the current Vagrantfile design is the result of over 1.5 years of use with this usage pattern across multiple LF Collaborative Projects

tykeal
2016-06-01 16:05
actually, that's probably closer to 2.5 years now...

ghaskins
2016-06-01 16:09
like I said, don’t interpret that as criticism, I was just curious what you ran into

ghaskins
2016-06-01 16:10

bramwelt
2016-06-04 03:49
@cbf: Hey Chris, here's where we're at. Jobs are getting triggered by PRs and merges on Github, but statuses are not being reported back. This is most likely a permissions issue. Builds are being ran on Z hosts as well, but currently fail due to a Go bug. x86 builds are currently failing due to some misconfiguration of docker on the system that I have yet to understand. I'll get you more info on Monday when I'm back in the office. Have a good weekend!

2016-06-09 16:04

cbf
2016-06-09 16:04
@ghaskins: where did we land with that?

cbf
2016-06-09 16:05

ramesh
2016-06-09 16:06
We are planning to automate this process only after successful merge.

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:08
@cbf: we currently put $arch in the tag for baseimage

ramesh
2016-06-09 16:08
for every successful merge in github, jenkins sends these images to docker hub

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:11
@cbf: https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage/tags/

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:13
one thing though, this works because of how we handle baseimages specifically

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:13
it _might_ make more sense to put the $arch in the name for other images so people may exploit the notion of :latest

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:14
e.g. “docker pull hyperledger/fabric-peer-x86_64” would just get whatever the latest image is

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:14
otherwise, they would need to fully qualify the version

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:15
though I suppose if they need to know $arch, they could synthesize the tag too

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:16
e.g. @ramesh and company could push images tagged with :$arch-$gitsha and the latest as $arch-latest

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:16
that should work equally well, i would think

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:17
@cbf: regarding automation, its still a manual process today, but I would love it if it could be automated

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:18
the process is a bit of a PITA for me today, but thankfully we update baseimage very infrequently

cbf
2016-06-09 16:18
hmmm

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:18
to be clear, I think Jenkins will make this easy to automate

ry
2016-06-09 16:18
ghaskins: it could probably be done via jenkins, feel free to take a look at the ci repo and start pushing patches

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:18
we just lacked that platform historically

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:18
@ry: yeah, i suspect that is the case

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:20
@ry: docker image generation I suspect will be fairly straight forward…it would be nice if we could automate the vagrant side too but in order to do that we would need an x86 worker that has facilities for running virtualbox

ghaskins
2016-06-09 16:20
(we may already have that today, not sure…just saying, that is one of the requirements)

ramesh
2016-06-09 16:22
yes, it is possible in jenkins.. I have submitted patch for review

bramwelt
2016-06-09 18:51
ghaskins: You are referring to the vagrant images in fabric, correct, not the x86 build servers?

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:08
@bramwelt: im not sure I am understanding the question, but I think the answer is “yes"

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:08
what I meant specifically was: today we can build the vagrant hyperledger/fabric-baseimage by doing “cd images/base; make vagrant"

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:09
and that will spin up a packer job on top of virtualbox, and produce a vagrant image suitable for pushing to atlas

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:09
it would be awesome to have that automated in jenkins, but it would require a worker that has access to creating its own virtualbox vms as part of its workload

bramwelt
2016-06-09 19:10
@ghaskins: Yes, that was what I was wondering.

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:12
im guessing this would mean some kind of static x86 build server, as any kind of dynamic one is likely to be a virtual worker and may not be compatible with nesting virtualbox

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:12
(though not impossible)

ghaskins
2016-06-09 19:12
depending on the hardware and HVM, it may allow nesting

bramwelt
2016-06-09 19:18
I'm pretty sure you can nest virtualbox under kvm

bramwelt
2016-06-09 19:19
It's just sorta silly though when you have a perfectly fine hypervisor already (kvm) :wink:

ghaskins
2016-06-09 20:02
:slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-06-09 20:02
it might be possible to generate the image somewhere other than virtualbox, but it would need to be qualified

bramwelt
2016-06-09 20:08
That's true.

ghaskins
2016-06-09 23:32
@bramwelt: note that there is no “fabric-base”, image literally…there is hyperledger/fabric-baseimage in docker which is built using the logical name of “base” in the makefile…e.g. base-image, base-image-clean, etc

ghaskins
2016-06-09 23:32
is that what you meant?

bramwelt
2016-06-09 23:33
@cbf: Comment 'reverify jenkins' on a PR

cbf
2016-06-09 23:33
danke

bramwelt
2016-06-09 23:34
@ghaskins: Awesome. That's exactly what I wanted to know. :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-06-09 23:34
(and yes, I was slightly inconsistent in that there is the names the makefile deals with being [base src ccenv peer membersrvc] and all the images use hyperledger/fabric-$name except base, which is baseimage

ghaskins
2016-06-09 23:34
(thus that override

ghaskins

https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/143/ has two patches, the initial commit and patch 2, which is a rebase. should patch 2 be committed, patch 1 won’t show up in the git log

ry
2016-06-10 00:57
just updated to patch 3 with a commit message edit. that is the commit message that will show up in git log

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:57
@ry i started watching the video, and I will finish it later…but one question I had right away was: how are the “changes” introduced for review?

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:57
ah, ok, got it

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:57
is it email to the list

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:57
push

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:57
?

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:57
ah, push to what?

ry
2016-06-10 00:57
git push origin HEAD:refs/for/{branch}

ry
2016-06-10 00:57
so git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:58
that's the thing I was talking about: you no longer off of a fork

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:58
ah, so in this model, everyone has commit access at some level to a single repo?

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:58
you work off of a clone of the main repo

ghaskins
2016-06-10 00:58
im not clear on the difference between a fork and a clone

ry
2016-06-10 00:58
you’ll need the pre-commit hook to generate the change ID to make it automagic.

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:58
and when you push upstream it puts it up for review

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:59
the fork is what you have on github in your own space like http://lehors.github.com/fabric

arnaud
2016-06-10 00:59
the clone is what you have on your local machine

ry
2016-06-10 00:59
ghaskins: the difference is your changes aren’t merged to your branch directly. it is very similar to a PR that hasn’t been merged.

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:00
at least, that's what I understood :wink:

ry
2016-06-10 01:00
admits that you could add two remotes: one to http://gerrit.hyp.org, one to github, and do both at once

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:00
ok, so to play this back: today with github: we have the upstream repo, a github fork, and a local clone

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:00
maybe you work in a different way?

ry
2016-06-10 01:00
but that might not be the best way to start :slightly_smiling_face:

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:00
right

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:01
i can do whatever locally, no one sees it, then I can push local -> fork, and its public, but not a PR, and then I can create a PR from there

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:01
yep

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:01
IIUC, in this model we have upstream repo and a local clone, and whatever I push to the local clone automatically gets something like a “PR” registered

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:02
well, you don't push to your local clone

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:02
sorry, commit

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:02
yeah, you can commit as much as you want, that remains private

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:02
(though if this works as I am describing, I probably will be, heh

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:02
when you push that creates the "PR"

ry
2016-06-10 01:03
https://www.zephyrproject.org/doc/contribute/gerrit.html is the basic workflow, s/zephyr/hyperledger/g

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:03
please @ry correct me I'm wrong

ry
2016-06-10 01:03

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:03

ry
2016-06-10 01:03

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:03
ok, so I basically do a git push from local->upstream, but rather than the normal “i have remote access” it does something else by making a review thingy in the Gerrit UI

arnaud
2016-06-10 01:04
that's it

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:04

2016-06-10 01:04

ry
2016-06-10 01:04
then, if you edit your pending change, you can git commit —amend and push a new patch without creating a new change.

ry
2016-06-10 01:04
ttyl

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:05

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:05

2016-06-10 01:05

ry
2016-06-10 01:05

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:05

ry
2016-06-10 01:06

ghaskins
2016-06-10 01:06

ry
2016-06-10 01:06

ghaskins

ry
2016-06-10 01:06
and can’t merge until the parent most commit merges

tykeal
2016-06-10 01:25
The zephyr docs don't talk about the git-review plugin, but I strongly recommend folks use that as it takes a lot of annoyances of the gerrit workflow out of the picture and makes it work really well

tykeal
2016-06-10 01:27
See this https://wiki.opendaylight.org/view/GettingStarted:Pulling,_Hacking,_and_Pushing_All_the_Code_from_the_CLI#Gerrit_Workflow for how OpenDaylight discusses it. You would find similar docs in the OpenStack project

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:19
We're having an issue with builds failing on x86. After one job has run on a build server, the second job will automatically fail because it can't clean the workspace. ``` java.io.IOException: remote file operation failed: /w/workspace/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric at hudson.remoting.Channel@78f9862c:hyp-x86_64-472: java.nio.file.AccessDeniedException: /w/workspace/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/docker/pkg/linux_amd64/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/protos.a ```

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:19
Is fabric being compiled as root?

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:20
Because the files that get generated can't be removed as they are owned by root.

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:20
@bramwelt: which environment?

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:20
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/job/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/146/console

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:20
vagrant/travis/jenkins

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:21
ah, not sure what jenkins does

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:21
i think on vagrant provisioning it does run a build in the setup.sh which is as root, but then then explicitly chowns the $GOPATH after that

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:21
It runs basically the same thing Travis does

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:21
minus all the setup

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:22
I saw that issue in vagrant once which inspired this comment: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/devenv/setup.sh#L93

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:22
but as far as what travis/jenkins do, I am not sure

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:26
Hmm, the GOPATH is owned by the jenkins user

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:30
``` jenkins@hyp-x86-64-195:~$ ls -l /w/workspace/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/docker/ total 8 drwxrwxr-x 2 jenkins jenkins 4096 Jun 10 15:19 bin drwxrwxr-x 3 jenkins jenkins 4096 Jun 10 15:13 pkg jenkins@hyp-x86-64-195:~$ ls -l /w/workspace/fabric-github-verify-x86_64/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/build/docker/pkg/ total 4 drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Jun 10 15:13 linux_amd64 ```

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:32
`build/docker` is owned by Jenkins, but `build/docker/pkg` is not. The Jenkins user can't sudo, so the only way for these files to have been created as root is if they were created in a docker container running as root

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:32
``` jenkins@hyp-x86-64-195:~$ docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-peer /bin/bash root@54706f656078:/opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# ```

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:33
@bramwelt: if the files were created in docker, they would be within the docker container unless they were built with a volume mount or something along those lines

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:34
this seems like somewhere in the jenkins process, someone ran “make peer” (or a superset) directly on jenkins itself, as root

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:34
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L130

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:35
A volume mount like this? :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:35
ah!

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:35
yes, i see your point now

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:35
I missed the build/docker/pkg at the end, sorry

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:36
(I didnt realize docker root could escape like that, heh

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:36
No worries! I'm not throwing blame or anything. We can definitely work around this for now too by bringing up a slave per build. :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:36
theres no reason that needs to run as root, we can probably figure out how to either remap uid in the volume or run the docker command as a unprivileged user

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:37
That's what I was hoping to hear.

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:37
please file an issue and ill take care of it

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:38
Sure thing!

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:39
my guess is this is permitted probably because docker itself had sudo or something

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:43
https://denibertovic.com/posts/handling-permissions-with-docker-volumes/

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:48
@bramwelt: the UID thing might be problematic for the reasons listed…but one good thing is, I don’t actually care about the data on the host side

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:48
its purely a cache so that subsequent rebuilds within the container can re-use previously generated artifacts

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:48
so, we might be able to change the approach to something like a data volume https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/volume_create/

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:49
though, that is only true for the ./pkg dir….hmmm

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:49
i do need the ./bin on the host side

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:49
Data volumes are a good idea. They just take a bit more work to manage and cleanup.

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:50
yeah, though make is good at that

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:50
(or, potentially good at that, i shouldnt speak since I havent used docker data volumes personally yet

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:50
but, it seems like it would be good at that, heh

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:51
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/1790

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:52
Not sure if you need more info...

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:52
hmm, it looks like data volumes are some ephemeral thing, like a docker container/image

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:52
i was hoping it was like a vdisk mount that I could store where I wanted

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:53
Ah, no.. the process is 1) run named docker container, 2) mount exposed volume on subsequent docker containers, 3) docker rm -v named container once done

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:54
hmm, might just have to hammer it with UID for now

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:54
(thx for the issue

bramwelt
2016-06-10 15:55
No problem! In about an hour, once I get to the office, I'll add the workaround to jenkins and retrigger the failed builds.

ghaskins
2016-06-10 15:56
ok, sounds good…sorry for the oversight

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:29
@ghaskins: Yes, we got dockerhub pushes working. They currently only run on merges to master that successfully build. Images are pushed as `hyperledgergithub/fabric-peer:$arch-$sha`

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:29
where $arch is either `x86_64` or `s390x`

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-06-16 19:31

ghaskins
2016-06-16 19:32

ghaskins
2016-06-16 19:32

ghaskins

ghaskins

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:36

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:38

ry
2016-06-16 19:39
@bramwelt: I do own that repo, but I don’t know anything about pushing to it

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:41
@ry: Oh, good! There are masked password fields in the global Jenkins configuration you can update to change which repo they go to.

ry
2016-06-16 19:41
@bramwelt: is this a webhook I need to set up or will it be pushing as me?

bramwelt
2016-06-16 19:42
@ry: See `include-raw-docker-image-deploy.sh` in the ci-management repo for the job. It gets pushed as the `DOCKER_HUB_USERNAME` defined in ENV

bmos299
2016-06-17 13:15
It seems like the Travis CI is catching a lot of failures because contributors aren't using Travis before submitting the PR. I know @ghaskins and many others count on it before submitting the PR. Is there a suggestion as to how to get others to be more diligent running Travis on the Push to their remote user account before submitting the PR?

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:18
If we wanted to encourage that, we could add an item to the checklist I suppose

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:19
i think more important than that is to have a “I have run ‘make checks’”, as it would be nice to flush out errors before burdening the CI pipeline in the first place

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:20
perhaps combine the two? “I have run ‘make checks’ and also verified that CI passes in my personal repository”

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:20
or something to that effect

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:20
related, as we add more linters to ‘make checks/linter’ we can relax that line about goimports

ramesh
2016-06-17 13:21
That will be great.. and Travis integration with github takes less than a min

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:22
yeah, perhaps the checklist item has a link to any instructions we want to provide on how to turn on travis

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:22
(I can confirm it is easy, as I do it against my own fork)

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:29
@sheehan @cbf any thoughts on above?

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:30
related, @ry will there be a parallel notion of “run CI against local repo before push” once we switch to Jenkins?

sheehan
2016-06-17 13:49
I don’t understand why Travis CI catching an issue is a problem. Why add an additional step to a PR submission?

sheehan
2016-06-17 13:50
I don’t see a problem with someone submitting a PR that doesn’t pass Travis CI. It just won’t be accepted until they resolve issues

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:53
@sheehan: that was kind of my thought…ultimately the only one that matters is the official one

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:54
the one argument I can see (not sure if this is what @bmos299 was getting at) is you could arguably increase S/N for maintainer/reviewers

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:54
(by not having a bunch of faulty PRs floating around)

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:56
I can also see the argument for having “make checks” in the checklist to try to encourage local testing before loading the CI pipeline…but the problem there is the checklist is really only officially part of the workflow _after_ you have already pushed to the personal fork

ghaskins
2016-06-17 13:56
so, its purpose would be more of an advisory/habit-forming kind than a literal checklist

sheehan
2016-06-17 13:58
I don’t have an issue with faulty or in-progress PRs. I encourage people to work in the open as they may receive valuable feedback sooner if someone chooses to look. I agree it’s useful for a dev to be aware of `make checks` and Travis because it is helpful to test things locally. I think we should probably update that checklist to say `make checks`. Not sure what to do about `golint` though as it generates a bunch of false positives

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:00
so maybe the checklist could also link to instructions for running Travis on your fork

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:01
yeah, regarding linters I think we should a) add “make checks” to the list, and b) clean up the linters section to remove the parts that are covered by “make checks” and encourage the more flaky linters with the caveats as we have them now

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:01
so, govet/goimports, those ones are solid now (IIUC), move those out of the explicit list

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:02
golint, not sure we can ever automate that one

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:02
I added `goimports` in https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/pull/1882

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:02
I’ll work on another PR to update the template

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:02
ah, I think I was waiting for CI on that that

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:02
ill take another look

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:02
any thoughts on something like “gofmt -s"

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:02
is that in the govet or golint category for reliability?

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:03
I need to look at what suggestions the simplify is making and see if there are cases where they don’t make sense

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:04
yeah, and I am not married to -s either

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:04
`goimports` runs `gofmt`, but there’s no way to specify the `-s` flag

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:04
so consider it the “can gofmt** be automated” endeavor

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:04
ah, ok, i didnt realize

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:04
perhaps non issue then

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:05
I assume that the gometalinter thing didn’t pan out? or should we revisit that?

sheehan
2016-06-17 14:14
didn’t work out. the complexity of gometaliner’s configuration resulted in lots of complaints

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:15
ah, bummer

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:15
looked promising

ramesh
2016-06-17 14:15
@sheehan: not as a mandatory step in the checklist but we can suggest contributors to test commits on their travis setup before submit PR. Anyway once the PR is submitted, every further commit will be tested on hyperledger/fabric travis.

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:16
ghaskins: no there isn't a special notion of running CI against a local repo before push, unless someone has their own local CI, or are using github + travis as their personal hosting to work on stuff before they submit

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:16
@tykeal: ok, but note that there is some semblance of integration today

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:17
our Jenkins configurations will be able to easily handle the load of multiple people pushing different submissions to the configuration

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:17
for instance, I can fork hyperledger/fabric to ghaskins/fabric, turn on travis, and the reports when i run the job show up in #

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:17
im just curious if jenkins would be similar (if we wanted it to be)

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:18
our largest project (OpenDaylight) sees close to 10,000 jenkins jobs a day

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:18
all the jenkins reports will be visible against the gerrit change as well as on the gerrit dashboard views for the specific project

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:19
@ramesh: the problem as I see it is one of getting the word out: the check-list is one of the most glaring / hard-to-ignore forms of media we have

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:19
and if there is a class of jobs, let's say $project-integration-$somequalifier than we can easily create a special view that collects all of those as well

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:19
but that said, I can be convinced either way…i just saw the checklist as the best vehicle to advertise the policy, should the policy be considered desirable

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:23
ghaskins: as an FYI, because of how the gerrit workflow operates. Not having that personal CI, while it can me some thrash in the verification jobs going between broken and fixed a lot, isn't too much of a problem. You mechanically cannot merge a non-passing submission unless the committer of the project explicitly votes to, but their voting around Jenkins does end up getting recorded

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:25
@tykeal: that sounds good to me

ghaskins
2016-06-17 14:25
as long as we are not concerned about the pipeline workload, I think we are good

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:28
oh believe me, we're not concerned about the pipeline workload. If your project gets anywhere near the size of OpenDaylight (our largest) in anything less than 1.5 years then I would be worried about the pipeline ;)

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:28
and even then, by that time I'm sure we'll have even better mechanisms in place for balancing out the workload

tykeal
2016-06-17 14:29
the most likely largest bottleneck would be external resources we don't have full control over or ability to easily scale out. Such as the Z system setups

ghaskins
2016-06-17 15:18

amundson
2016-06-18 14:44
does the use of JJB make it easy to replicate the jenkins environment locally (say in a vm), or is that still a fairly complex undertaking? (for testing updates to JJBs for example)

ry
2016-06-18 17:05
You would still need openstack and the like

tykeal
2016-06-19 03:44
amundson: ry you would only need a local OpenStack if you wanted to test components related to dynamic spin-up that is adding additional minions past the lead node. In general, if you've got a local jenkins that has one or more attached builders that have the same labels associated to them that match what we use your good

tykeal
2016-06-19 03:45
amundson: ry we presently only have on project that makes use of multi-node dynamic build slaves

ramesh

@ghaskins: We are again seeing the java.io.IOException: in Z builds

ramesh
2016-06-21 17:03
java.io.IOException:

ramesh
2016-06-21 17:03
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-github-verify-z/136/console

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:10
my guess is perhaps this system had artifacts that persisted from the runs before the fix went in?

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:11
can someone go in an manually remove the build area and then see if it continues?

ry
2016-06-21 17:12
I will in a bit

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:13
cool, if it starts with a clean fs and still does that, we have a problem but I suspect it was just left over from before

ry
2016-06-21 17:14
I agree. I suspect this issue will keep popping up until all outstanding pull requests are rebased the past the merge of the fix

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:14
oh, is that how jenkins works?

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:14
i found out recently that travis merges the pr branch with master

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:15
(which is probably ideal, actually)

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:15
I just didnt know it did that

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:15
IMO it would be nice if Jenkins could too, or at least have them do it the same way

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:17
@ry @ramesh it is conceivable that we could start to do more and more within docker, builds, unit-tests, etc

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:17
that would isolate the CI environment to a degree

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:17
is this something worth exploring?

ry
2016-06-21 17:18
Jenkins pulls the commit ID, and parents. I assert merging a PR with master before building is a misfeature

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:18
oh really? i see it as the opposite…can I ask why?

ry
2016-06-21 17:19
Since you don't know master is the target branch

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:19
it seems to me that the most relevant config is PR + latest

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:19
oh, i see what you mean

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:19
well, ok, so substitute “master” for “intended target” (assuming we can ascertain that)

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:19
is it then “ok” ?

ry
2016-06-21 17:20
Perhaps merging with the parent branch is OK, but that prevents non mergable changes from building, which is probably less bad

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:20
isnt that the point?

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:21
we want to find out if the proposed change plays nice with the most realistic place it would go

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:21
(though I understand its a constantly moving target)

ry
2016-06-21 17:21
I'm here to support what you guys want. I'm only mildly against merge before build.

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:21
well, I also value experience here

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:21
i’ve never run a large scale CI

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:22
I thought Travis was simply building the branch that the PR submitter built…but I found out later it is actually merging to master/parent

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:22
to me, this made some sense for the reasons I mentioned

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:23
but, I dont have enough experience with CI in production to know what wrinkles this may cause either

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:24
related, it strikes me that the concept is the most useful if it can automatically respin an unmerged+open PR every time master/parent is updated

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:25
i can see the merit of the data point of knowing if the change you made against the base you developed on passes CI…but it seems that is less interesting than whether it passes with HEAD

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:26
ideally, we could know both

ry
2016-06-21 17:28
where I see this as creating problems is long-lived feature branches and the like. you may not care that CI isn’t passing on the eventual merge to your parent branch, because you’re ripping out a lot of stuff, or you have two feature branches that are aware of each other but not yet merged. for instance, on one project I’m on, we have changes that need to go in across multiple repos at once, or nothing works. So building the feature branch and running tests against the master on the other project will never work.

ry
2016-06-21 17:28
I propose we table my theoretical concerns about this for now, though

ry
2016-06-21 17:30
I’ve cleaned up the two -z builders for now

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:33
ah, i see…yes this makes sense

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:34
the “automerge” approach really only makes sense for a PR like scenario

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:35
so, if the CI jobs can differentiate between branches and PRs, we could divide the policy decision on that predicate

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:35
thx you for the z cleanup…lets see what happens now

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:36
if the —user patch didnt work, we’ll have to take more drastic measures in the build system

ry
2016-06-21 17:38
I’m almost certain it worked

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:38
yeah, it did on x86 at least

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:39
im wondering if the z platform had a different docker install or something that handled it differently

ry
2016-06-21 17:39
on x86 I set the builder recycle time to 60 idle seconds

ry
2016-06-21 17:39
so provided we don’t have a queue, no builder should run two builds.

ry
2016-06-21 17:39
on Z, there is no chance of recycling

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:39
if you are right that jenkins is building PRs against their submitted base rather than HEAD, I think you are right that this could persist until the PRs that predate the fix are closed out

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:40
it seems to me that this wasnt an issue of timing as much as it was that the build was spraying UID 0 artifacts into the tree and then causing subsequent grief

ry
2016-06-21 17:40
if you added something like a “git log -2” to the top of the build job, you could see for yourself what the parent is

ry
2016-06-21 17:41
yes, you’re correct it isn’t timing. I’m saying building was less impacted on x86 because the builders get recycled

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:41
I would just add “git rev-parse HEAD” or something like that

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:41
oh, gotcha, sorry

ry
2016-06-21 17:41
sure, that works\

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:41
actually your idea is probably better

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:42
mine would only show the PR sha

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:42
but, same idea

ry
2016-06-21 17:42
sure. Just show the parent or grandparent.\

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:42
“print-context-somehow()"

ry
2016-06-21 17:42
if you have a bunch of dependent changes, it would be best to get back to your merged parent, but that isn’t visible in git really

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:43
i wonder if there is a rev-parse type command that can show it

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:43
I know you can have it walk back to the last tag

ghaskins
2016-06-21 17:43
i wonder if there is a mode for branch

ry
2016-06-21 17:47
sure. lots of our builds say something a little non-sensical like “15.09 + 1400 commits” which isn’t helpful, really, but it’s the same idea

2016-06-21 22:51

2016-07-01 17:37

hgabor
2016-08-08 20:53
Shouldn't we write all the docker container logs to stdout to make debugging easier? I mean in Jenkins

ry
2016-08-08 20:57
I have no objection

hgabor
2016-08-09 12:43
okay but how to do it 1) easily and quickly 2) with the possibility for users to suppress such logs?

hgabor
2016-08-09 12:45
quick & dirty: see patchsets 13-14 (https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/317/13) and the docker/container related files. my simple and stupid suggestion is to create an IF there which checks if an environment var e.g. CONTAINER_LOGGING is set, and if it is then the logs get written out. And after this we should just set that environment variable on the Jenkins machines.

hgabor
2016-08-09 12:45
opinions?

jcarrivick
2016-08-10 00:31
has joined #ci-pipeline

jcarrivick
2016-08-10 01:10
So I have figured out what is causing the "random" bdd failures in Jenkins where requests timeout. Said issue seems to exhibit itself mostly with `@issue 1000 - chaincode example02 with 4 peers and 1 membersrvc, test crash fault`. What happens is that sometimes when the peers come back up they get new IPs and the root VP still tries to connect to the old IPs. I've created an issue on Jira to track it: https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-5

ramesh
2016-08-10 15:07
@jcarrivick: we have similar issue tracked in github https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/issues/2346 but this was closed couple days.. @tuan suspected this could be docker version issue in jenkins

ramesh
2016-08-10 15:25
@ry: please install https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/Conditional+BuildStep+Plugin

ry
2016-08-10 17:07
@ramesh: it was already installed, but I ran the update. The update requires a Jenkins restart, so it will be a little bit for the very latest version to be installed

ramesh
2016-08-10 17:19
Thanks ry. I am planning to submit patch for ci skip.

ry
2016-08-10 17:21

ramesh
2016-08-10 17:21
when commit message is having ci skip

ry
2016-08-10 17:22

ramesh
2016-08-10 17:24
skip build when user submits only documentation changes..

ry
2016-08-10 17:27

ramesh
2016-08-10 17:28
earlier with github and jenkins we have this feature.. so, thought of implementing this..

gennady.laventman
2016-08-22 13:09
Hello. How I can start new jenkins build without making new commit/push?

hgabor
2016-08-22 13:18
open the last build from gerrit, login jenkins and push retrigger (left side)

tykeal
2016-08-22 13:18
gennady.laventman: to retrigger a verify leave a comment in gerrit of 'recheck' to remerge (which rebuilds the head) and leave a comment of 'remerge'

tykeal
2016-08-22 13:19
hgabor: most folks don't, and won't, have access to using the jenkins UI for triggering builds

hgabor
2016-08-22 13:20
I see

gennady.laventman
2016-08-22 13:42

ry
2016-08-23 18:13
this is done - if any other projects want this policy, let me know directly

2016-08-24 03:07
lets see what happens

ry
2016-08-24 03:16
interesting

cbf
2016-08-24 15:56
only changed layers are pulled

2016-08-24 15:57

ry
2016-08-24 18:00
ok.

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:04
so, the problem I am facing right now is, it seems that the vagrant+jenkins environments are too divergent

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:04
i cant simultaneously make both happy

ry
2016-08-24 18:06
the jenkins+vagrant environment diverges from your local workspace?

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:14
well, one thing I am seeing is that I am having trouble managing docker tags because what works in vagrant/1.12 doesnt work in jenkins/1.8 or vice versa

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:14
so I basically have to choose which one I want to break

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:15
part of this is being exacerbated by something that might be a fixable problem

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:15
that is: it seems that the CI build is running parts of the build twice (suboptimally)

ry
2016-08-24 18:15
oh, really? that does seem sub optimal

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:15
because of this, I had to add “-f” to docker tag to force it to retag, but this isnt supported in 1.12

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:16
hold on, let me find the conversation with Ramesh

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:16
ok, take a look at this log

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:16
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/546/console

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:17
fabric-src is built at 13:27:06

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:17
but then it mysteriously is rebuilt at 13:57:08

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:17
for reasons that are not clear

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:18
this has two implications: #1 the build is not as efficient as it could be

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:18
#2 to work around it, I later added “-f” to docker tag to force it, but this tag is not supported in 1.12 so vagrant breaks

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:19
its not clear to me why the CI build thought it needed to rebuild the image, but it should have been available

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:19
(and to be clear, I am not pointing the finger at anyone…it could be a bug in my makefile)

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:19
the bottom line is: i dont know why that is happening but its causing problems

ry
2016-08-24 18:21
is there a verbosity flag or flags you could turn up?

ry
2016-08-24 18:28
I’m looking through https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/fabric/fabric-macros.yaml;h=28b18e9f8baacce70db51e9cbb131993319bd856;hb=HEAD which shows where make is invoked. probably not the right place to change it

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:36
@ry, adding -d to “make” will cause it to spew a bunch of stuff about the decisions it is making

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:37
that might clue us in as to why the target was believed to be out of date

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:38
i cant tell where behave is being run in that scenario

ry
2016-08-24 18:40
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/fabric/include-raw-fabric-behave.sh;h=845d63632d34fedd8bc31ab346bac3539362fbc4;hb=HEAD

ry
2016-08-24 18:40
line 12

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:40
ah!

ry
2016-08-24 18:40
invoked from line 80 of https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/fabric/fabric-macros.yaml;h=28b18e9f8baacce70db51e9cbb131993319bd856;hb=HEAD

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:40
i wonder if the sed is triggering the rebuild

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:41
theres nothing wrong with patching the file in this manner per se, but doing it after the system has already performed some builds will make the images be rebuilt

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:42
it would be better if this file could be patched before _any_ make operations are performed

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:42
that would avoid the cycle

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:42
(i cant easily tell what files have an impact, so there is a gross “rebuild if _any_ source files changed” rule

ry
2016-08-24 18:42
propose a change to the ci-m repo - one downside is we can’t really test that in isolation

ry
2016-08-24 18:43
well, actually, now that you see the shell scripts, could you debug it locally?

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:44
i think all thats needed is to move line 11 from https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/fabric/include-raw-fabric-behave.sh;h=845d63632d34fedd8bc31ab346bac3539362fbc4;hb=HEAD to something that is more “init"

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:45
i dont know enough about this environment to suggest where that might want to go

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:45
but conceptually, that should fix the churn

ry
2016-08-24 18:45
@ramesh - any pointers here?

ramesh
2016-08-24 18:48
@ghaskins: Why to move line 11 ?

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:48
@ramesh i believe it is the cause of the fabric-src rebuild

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:49
if you run “make X” and then sed a file managed by git (such as the compose.yml in the above link), a subsequent “make” (including “make behave”) will trigger a complete rebuild

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:50
(because the makefile cannot tell what impact a change to a .yml file might have on binaries)

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:50
we could try to make this smarter, of course, but its tricky

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:50
(and generally, fraught with risk)

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:51
generally speaking, its better to be conservative and rebuild too often than not often enough

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:51
the first wastes build-system/CI time, the second wastes human debugging time

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:52
therefore, I am proposing that the environmental touch up of the yaml should ideally occur during initialization, before any other builds have occured

ramesh
2016-08-24 18:53
Oh ok.. this is working in current build process. any changes related to this in recent patch?

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:53
no, i think this patch just highlighted the problem

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:53
my guess is, if we go look, we will see that the CI process has been compiling fabric-src twice for a while now

ry
2016-08-24 18:53
given that build times haven’t varied much over time, yes

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:53
i havent confirmed this though

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:54
(it broke here because I am trying to tag something != “latest"

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:54
latest tags are fairly lax, you can tag it over and over

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:54
non latest tags do not like to be retagged

ry
2016-08-24 18:55
the successful builds have taken about an hour for a while: https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/buildTimeTrend

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:55
since this patch introduced non-latest tagging, it broke when it found out that fabric-src was already tagged

ramesh
2016-08-24 18:56
yes that is true.. So, fabric-src always build when there is a change in the binaries..

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:57
close: when there is a change to any files managed by git

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:57
(including compose.yml)

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:57
(which makes sense when you really think about it: if fabric-src is a container of the src, it is invalidated if the source changes

ry
2016-08-24 18:58
ghaskins if you see somewhere obvious to park the sed script, I’m all ears

ghaskins
2016-08-24 18:58
@ry ok, i dont really understand the flow here, but ill try

ghaskins
2016-08-25 21:53

ghaskins
2016-08-25 21:54

ghaskins
2016-08-25 21:54
(though ultimately, its decoupled)

cbf
2016-08-27 00:43

ry
2016-08-27 00:44

cbf
2016-08-27 00:45
we run make dist-clean which deletes all of the docker images

cbf
2016-08-27 00:45
hence we cannot reuse the baseimage (which almost never changes)

cbf
2016-08-27 00:45
and that takes the longest to build

cbf
2016-08-27 00:46
I don’t know when the build changed

cbf
2016-08-27 00:46
the Makefile was changed recently to avoid having to build baseimage every time

cbf

line 8 in ci-management/jjb/fabric/include-raw-fabric-clean-environment.sh

2016-08-27 00:47

2016-08-30 21:57

ghaskins
2016-08-30 21:58

ghaskins
2016-08-30 21:58

ghaskins
2016-08-30 21:59

cbf
2016-08-31 13:48

cbf
2016-08-31 14:00
@binhn @sheehan @jonathanlevi @hgabor @tamas @simon @muralisr @garisingh - @ghaskins and I were just discussing (lamenting) the state of the build and some of the patches that are looking to simplify and shorten the build. We started talking about https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/721/ which was attempting to eliminate unnecessary builds of the base image every time we build. We had previously discussed pulling out the build for the various base images into a separate repository and then controlling the specific version by referencing a specific tag in the fabric (and other) builds where we are explicitly calling out a bump of a version tag to push, and we are pulling a previously explicitly tagged version from atlas or dockerhub.

tamas
2016-08-31 14:01
has joined #ci-pipeline

simon
2016-08-31 14:01
has joined #ci-pipeline

garisingh
2016-08-31 14:01
has joined #ci-pipeline

cbf
2016-08-31 14:01
I like this approach as it is cleaner, and we can simplify and reduce the time to build

cbf
2016-08-31 14:03
I would propose we pull out images/base into its own repository with the same set of maintainers

cbf
2016-08-31 14:04
and we adapt its build pipeline to include an explicit change required to push a version that is governed under 2+2 merge policy

hgabor
2016-08-31 14:04
so this would mean having the docker image related things in that other repo, right?

ghaskins
2016-08-31 14:04
to be clear, this is only currently w.r.t. the baseimage for docker and vagrant

ghaskins
2016-08-31 14:05
i envision things like the fabric-peer image will remain in fabric.git, and simply reference the base image via tag/version

2016-08-31 14:05

ghaskins
2016-08-31 19:20
im sure its written down somewhere, but I dont know where…but the policy as I understand it is someone makes a PR to the maintainer.txt file and if a majority of the existing maintainers accept it, it is merged

ghaskins
2016-08-31 19:20
at least for fabric

ghaskins
2016-08-31 19:20

ghaskins
2016-08-31 19:20

ghaskins
2016-08-31 19:20

ghaskins

amundson
2016-08-31 20:58
@cbf - might want to avoid the regex character '.' in your branch name. I remember it causing issues in obscure places (jenkins, IIRC) in the past.

amundson
2016-08-31 21:00
wasn't jenkins specific per-se, was something to do with git ref matching

cbf
2016-08-31 21:31
hmmm, we used that previously https://github.com/hyperledger-archives/fabric/tree/v0.5-developer-preview

cbf
2016-08-31 21:34
k8s and docker use something similar

cbf
2016-08-31 21:34
thanks for the h/u though

ghaskins
2016-08-31 21:43
I can't comment on the regex problem, but I would suggest something like v0.6.x for the branch name to allow for 0.6.1, etc

ghaskins
2016-08-31 21:43
If the dots are a problem, perhaps v0_6_x

amundson
2016-08-31 21:50
for sawtooth, we are using X-Y (0-6) for branch name and vX.Y.Z (v0.6.0) for tags. seemed close to the OSS projects I saw (mostly looked at gnome)

cbf
2016-08-31 21:52
https://docs.google.com/document/d/19hZBOj4QklSJa2Fj3kHEwx1_R1T1rdRTXBseF6mzCN0/edit?usp=sharing

amundson
2016-08-31 21:53
some of those projects use _ in tags and - in branches

cbf
2016-08-31 21:53
this is the version naming taxonomy proposal uses semver

amundson
2016-08-31 21:57
@cbf - I'm not seeing much utility in appending the -developer-preview, and only -alpha, -beta, -rcN before major releases (like, 1.0 presumably you would want some rc versions)

amundson
2016-08-31 21:58
(I'm thinking of deb, rpm, pypi versions here - not necessarily how the branch is categorized)

cbf
2016-08-31 21:59
fair enough

cbf
2016-08-31 21:59
the developer preview could be web only, I suppose

cbf
2016-08-31 21:59
we definitely don’t want to lead people on

amundson
2016-08-31 22:00
this is what our core deb file looks like: python-sawtooth-core_0.7.1-git41.g4ab31e2-1_amd64.deb

amundson
2016-08-31 22:01
git41 == 41 commits since the v0.7.0 tag

amundson
2016-08-31 22:01
g4ab31e2 == 4ab31e2 commit hash

amundson
2016-08-31 22:01
the intent is that this version number is prior to 0.7.1 (so the same as alpha/beta/rc as far as sorting)

amundson
2016-08-31 22:02
when we build a tagged version, it would just be "0.7.1"

amundson
2016-08-31 22:03
in theory, this will allow us to output deb/rpm/whatever from jenkins into a repo and have the update process for the target package manager work seemlessly

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:42
@ry around?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:43
one of the things I wanted to talk to you about was getting a jenkins environment that will be conducive to taking over the “baseimage” pipeline

ry
2016-09-07 01:43
OK. what do you need?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:43
ultimately what we need is a jenkins job that has the ability to run vmx-based virtualbox workloads

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:43
generally that sounds like “bare metal worker” to me, but I suppose a properly configured VM could suffice too if that makes things easier

ry
2016-09-07 01:44
could you point me to something I could read (or just give me a lecture) on how this workflow would work?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:44
sure, it would be basically automating what is in here:

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:45
https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/tree/master/images/base

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:45
in a nutshell, I need a jenkins job that could invoke “make” in that tree

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:45
(though @cbf and I have aspirations to break out the baseimage to its own repo eventually

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:45
but effectively, same idea

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:46
digging deeper, that makefile is going to, amoung other things, run “packer” which will then drive a virtualbox/vagrant based configuration

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:47
its all automated, but it does need the underlying host to support vmx/virtualbox

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:47
the input to the job will be a git-commit hook, and the output will be an image pushed to atlas

ry
2016-09-07 01:47
I’ll need to talk to people, I don’t know if we’re doing this (or if any of our choices might prohibit it).

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:48
sure thing

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:48
fwiw, right now, we (read: me) do this manually

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:48
for one, its a PITA for me to qualify/release the image

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:48
but that is a minor thing

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:49
the bigger issue is, its a risk to have only one person that knows how to do it AND they posses the credentials to make unilateral releases

ry
2016-09-07 01:49
could you gin up a test job in ci-management repo that would basically test if the first step is possible (using packer to drive the next step)

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:49
obviously I trust myself, heh, but those are the facts

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:50
i assume you mean to see if the ci-management environment has the requisite resources?

ry
2016-09-07 01:50
basically, what is the minimal test that can be done to prove this is possible at all in our current environment?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:50
like vmx

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:50
ok, that should be easy, hold on

ry
2016-09-07 01:50
I assume there will need to be some apt-getting and the like

ry
2016-09-07 01:51

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:51

ry
2016-09-07 01:51

ghaskins
2016-09-07 01:51

ry
2016-09-07 01:51

holocron
2016-09-07 18:22

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:38

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:38

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:40
Perhaps there is a way to hand edit the Dockerfile for the java image and use the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage in the FROM statuement and add a RUN statement to install openjdk (which should pull from the s390x repos)

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:41
I first ran into this java issue last week.

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:42
my impression from the above snippet is the problem is with gradle-..bin

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:43
no

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:43
the exec format error is usually indicative of running a docker image that was built for another platform.

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:43
that's been my experience

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:43
I think the problem is in scripts/provision/host.sh

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:44
```scripts/provision/host.sh:update-java-alternatives -s java-1.8.0-openjdk-amd64 ```

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:44
ah, yep

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:44
and this applies to ppc64le as well

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:44
agreed

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:45
this should be more generic to point to the arch specific java dir

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:45
i agree

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:45
oh, we could just refactor the platform to install jre8+

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:45
part of the problem is the base installs default-jre and then the java config adds jre8+alternatives

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:45
would it be easier if the entire platform just installed jre8?

ghaskins
2016-09-07 18:46
(I wouldnt mind this personally, I have code that can take advantage of 8 that I had to disable on account of devenv installing jre7

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:52
I already have jre8 installed. ```# dpkg -l | grep jre ii default-jre 2:1.8-56ubuntu2 ppc64el Standard Java or Java compatible Runtime ii default-jre-headless 2:1.8-56ubuntu2 ppc64el Standard Java or Java compatible Runtime (headless) ii openjdk-8-jre:ppc64el 8u91-b14-3ubuntu1~16.04.1 ppc64el OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT ii openjdk-8-jre-headless:ppc64el 8u91-b14-3ubuntu1~16.04.1 ppc64el OpenJDK Java runtime, using Hotspot JIT (headless) ```

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 18:52
still see the same issue

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:52
i believe the issue lies in the contents of the Dockerfile used to build the java image

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:53
The FROM statement is using an x86 docker image

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:53
if you manually pull down openjdk:8 and try and run it on z it should fail

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:55
i am not sure why they don't use the hyperledger/fabric-baseimage in the FROM statement

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:55
and then just install openjdk using apt-get

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:59
This is the Docker file used to build the javaenv Docker image...

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:59
FROM openjdk:8 RUN wget https://services.gradle.org/distributions/gradle-2.12-bin.zip -P /tmp --quiet RUN unzip -q /tmp/gradle-2.12-bin.zip -d /opt && rm /tmp/gradle-2.12-bin.zip RUN ln -s /opt/gradle-2.12/bin/gradle /usr/bin ADD javashimsrc.tar.bz2 /root ADD protos.tar.bz2 /root WORKDIR /root # Build java shim after copying proto files from fabric/proto RUN core/chaincode/shim/java/javabuild.sh

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:59
from /src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric/images/javaenv

harrijk
2016-09-07 18:59
http://Dockerfile.in

srirama_sharma
2016-09-07 19:02
Yes. That way we won’t have dependency on any external (outside hyperledger) docker image

cbf
2016-09-07 20:44
@ry problems with Jira and Gerrit?

cbf
2016-09-07 20:44
nginx down again?

ry
2016-09-07 20:48
@cbf they look like they’re up to me, I’ll ask if there was an outage

cbf
2016-09-07 20:49

cbf
2016-09-07 20:49

ry
2016-09-07 20:50
which link? the open a helpdesk ticket link?

harrijk
2016-09-07 21:35
@srirama_sharma @ghaskins i was able to get the make process build the hyperledger/fabric-javaenv docker image for z Systems by updating fabric/images/javaenv/Dockerfile.in. i removed the FROM statement and added the following two statements: FROM hyperledger/fabric-baseimage RUN apt-get install -y openjdk-8-jdk However... the javabuild.sh script fails with the following messages: An exception occurred applying plugin request [id: 'java'] > Failed to apply plugin [id 'osdetector'] > Could not create an instance of type com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetectorExtension_Decorated. I dug into this some more and was able to turn on debug for the gradle build and just as I suspected, this version of gradle does not support the s390x platform. Gradle build debug messages: 1:21:50.305 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] ... 73 more 21:21:50.306 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] Caused by: kr.motd.maven.os.DetectionException: unknown os.arch: s390x 21:21:50.306 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] at kr.motd.maven.os.Detector.detect(Detector.java:54) 21:21:50.307 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] at com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetector$Impl.<init>(OsDetector.java:55) 21:21:50.308 [ERROR] [org.gradle.BuildExceptionReporter] at com.google.gradle.osdetector.OsDetector.<clinit>(OsDetector.java:27)

harrijk
2016-09-07 21:38
If I comment out the javabuild.sh RUN step in the javaenv docker image build Dockerfile, the rest of the make build process completed without error on the s390x platform. So I think the openjdk x86 docker image being used as a base for the build of the javaenv docker image along with gradle not supporting the s390x platform are the current issues with building 0.6 on the s390x platform.

silliman
2016-09-07 21:50
has joined #ci-pipeline

2016-09-09 14:06
@ghaskins : any inputs

ghaskins
2016-09-09 14:19
@ramesh this was by design: https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/blob/master/Makefile#L90

ghaskins
2016-09-09 14:19
the unit tests dont need the membersrvc-image

ghaskins
2016-09-09 14:19
if another task requires it, i would recommend making it explicit

cbf
2016-09-09 16:15
what happened? seems like there is a dependency

ramesh
2016-09-09 16:17
yes I have submitted a patch in CI to build membersrvc image

cbf
2016-09-09 16:19
kk

cbf
2016-09-09 16:26
@ry please add @garisingh to the list of fabric and f-t-r maintainers

cbf
2016-09-09 16:26
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/975/

ry
2016-09-09 16:38
@cbf invites sent.

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:45
@cbf the overall issue is that the jenkins “image push” task has an implicit dependency on image creation that was being satisfied by the behave tests running

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:45
once behave was removed from the equation, the image was no longer being built

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:46
the correct solution (IMO) is one of two options I’ve discussed with Ramesh

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:46
option 1 - the jenkins flow is “test building” (by building everything), “run unit-tests”, and “push images"

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:47
option 2 - “run unit tests” (ensuring unit-test deps are met), and “push images” (ensuring image pushing deps are met

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:48
but for the short term, Ramesh just explicitly builds the membersrvc-image in the unit-test step just to satisfy the current implicit dep

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:49
to put it another way, i do not think we should support implicit dependencies except for one possible mode: and that is, if all dependencies are known to be built anyway

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:49
(i.e. option 1)

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:51
(personally I think even for option 1, the “push images” task should still express its dependencies (e.g. “make images” should run first)

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:51
the build should do a no-op if there is no work to do

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:58
@ry i know you are super busy, but I am wondering if we can push the ball a little further on the “vagrant in jenkins” work

ghaskins
2016-09-09 16:59
im not sure what the environment is like or if its conducive to a non LF person coming in, but if you gave me proper access to at least a jenkins task to configure, i could play

ghaskins
2016-09-09 17:00
ive used jenkins before, i think I could get fairly far with just a blank project that I could point at a git tree and fire off runs

ry
2016-09-09 17:00

ghaskins

2016-09-13 01:10

2016-09-13 01:10

ry
2016-09-13 01:10
