ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:32
@ry you are talking about the two tiered trigger-build+tagged build solution?

ry
2016-09-14 02:35
@ghaskins: yeah

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:36
cool, that seems tenable

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:36
we could have one trigger job, and I envision 4 builders

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:36
(vagrant, docker-x86, docker-ppc, docker-z)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:36
i suppose we might have to manually trigger all 4 from the trigger job, but that seems managable

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:37
next “unknown” is how to manage tags via gerrit

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:37
(I know part of the magic is using annotated tags, but we might have a learning curve getting it all working)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:38
im thinking workflow is: someone submits an annotated tag for review…if it gets the requisite +2s, its merged, which kicks the trigger job, which flows down...

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:39
thoughts?

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:39
there would presumably be 1 or more other patches that flow through gerrit prior to the tag commit that actually change the logic

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:40
those shouldnt trigger the jobs that do the push, but we should have some kind of -verify job run on those

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:40
right now, I have 4 basic targets: make vagrant|vagrant-local|docker|docker-local

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:41
the -local variants run the same logic as the non-local, except they dont push the image to atlas/dockerhub

ghaskins
2016-09-14 02:41
so, the verify job could use those

ry
2016-09-14 03:13
I’ve never used tags in that way. I’ve always just laid the tags down

ry
2016-09-14 03:13
in my role as release engineer

ry
2016-09-14 03:18
I just tried pushing a tag for review, and it just took the tag: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=lf-sandbox.git;a=commit;h=de72c6e3ea837529a6bfb84fd63384d9738dbca2

ghaskins
2016-09-14 03:18
Hmm, maybe you have privs

ry
2016-09-14 03:18
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=lf-sandbox.git;a=tag;h=refs/tags/TEST_TAG is more interesting

ghaskins
2016-09-14 03:18
I'll try mine

ry
2016-09-14 03:21
:disappointed: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/repo-discuss/VV_xj6ftvoY

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:18
So it seems we could use tags, but not via review/approval

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:22
Ultimately what I would like to see is some way to incorporate multilateral voting into pushing a new baseimage release

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:22
Each release should also be tagged, so I was thinking that could kill two birds with one stone

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:22
But perhaps there is a different workflow to consider

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:23
Here's an idea. We could do something in the filesystem itself

ghaskins
2016-09-14 12:25
A certain kind of update to this file (after going through voting) would trigger a CI pipeline that tags the release and initiates the builder processes

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:15
@ry playing around with this

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:15
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/sandbox/job/test-multi/

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:15
goal is to have one multi-config that can do all three docker arch builds

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:15
(of course, I can only test x86 atm)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:16
but one thing that is interesting, its using master node for the top-level but then properly delegating to the (one and only) x86 axis

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:16
do you think I should also constrain the top-level build to a label?

ghaskins
2016-09-14 16:16
or is this fine?

ry
2016-09-14 17:02
It's fine

ry
2016-09-14 17:02
You could constrain it but we need a static node to park the job on, which would be master

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:12
ok, thats what I figured

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:12
it seems the only reason to constrain is when the job has specific requirements of the worker

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:12
(e.g. VMX, or x86)

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:13
please don't use matrix jobs!

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:13
use the ability of JJB to build a matrix for you instead

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:13
matrix jobs have a sever stability problem inside of jenkins

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:14
s/sever/severe/

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:23
@tykeal i assume by matrix job you mean a jenkins multi-config?

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:24
ultimately, i am open to whatever you guys recommend

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:24
we are going to need 4 basic types of build: vagrant (x86), docker-x86, docker-z, docker-p

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:24
matrix job type of which the multi-config job step type is a variant

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:24
and two classes of build

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:24
all of that can be done via JJB

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:24
release (artifacts pushed to public repo) and patch verify

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:25
you'll end up with a specific job for each combination

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:25
but which looks horrible in the Jenkins UI but it's a lot better for jenkins

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:25
I dont care how those are expressed (too much, though I do hate DRY violations)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
the patch verify job trigger should be straight forward gerrit integration

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
the release push job is a subset of merge trigger

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:26
we strongly recommend against using the jenkins matrix facilities since they're not well supported, and if you ever get to the point where you have a lot of jobs running in your system they cause jenkins to have extreme management issues

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
(only certain merges will result in a release)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
ok…thats fine

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
like I said, my requirements are more high-level

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:26
i dont care how we enact them into jenkins very much

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:27
so, whatever best practices etc, i am open to them

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:27
just trying to save you from having to re-architect later ;)

ghaskins
2016-09-14 17:27
ty

tykeal
2016-09-14 17:27
it's taken ODL ~3 months to do a transition off of matrix jobs after we finally figured out how bad they really were when we got to ~1750 jobs in the system

2016-09-20 14:51

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:32

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:32

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:32

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:33

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:34

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:34

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:34

cbf
2016-09-23 12:34

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:34
not sure what that would look like, but that would solve the problem

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:35
well, the way we have gerrit configured, _gerrit_ creates merge records

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:35
its just that users cannot submit them

ry
2016-09-23 12:35
On other projects we use the --no-ff as noted

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:36
so its not that we are merge record free per se, we just only have one entity that can generate them

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:36
@ry, cool

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:36
we could only grant the “push merge” ACL to maintainers or something, to limit the risk

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:37
whats unclear to me is, is it easy to spy the difference between a simple branch sync and other type of merge records when they get submitted for review

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:37
my guess is: unintended merge records probably wouldnt have a ChangeID

ry
2016-09-23 12:37
A pure merge won't generate a review

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:37
so maybe that would be a good gate

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:38

ghaskins
2016-09-23 12:38

ry
2016-09-23 12:39

ghaskins

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:30
@cbf regarding PR 1671, I had discussion with @ghaskins and here is the summary of it.. (please bear with it as its quite descriptive) with the initial changes suggested by @ghaskins to generalize and use fabric-baseimage & openjdk8 in http://Dockerfile.in, we see a build issue on x86. This is because we are using Ubuntu 14.04 for x86 baseimage which doesn't have Java8. But that is a pre-req for Java Shim. So approach with very little deviation would be to use baseimage for Power and z as they use Ubuntu 16.04 for baseimage and continue with existing code for x86 until we bump the base OS to 16.04 for x86. This was agreed by @ghaskins provided you are in agreement too. Now the point is either to go with my first patchset-1 or use 2 http://Dockerfiles.in based on your last comment. In the latter case, we would still need to have ARCH condition in Makefile so leaves it no different than my approach in patchset-1. Moreover, having two Dockerfiles with almost same contents will lead to violation of DRY / proliferation of code and doesn’t help getting rid of ARCH condition check in Makefile. @ghaskins is convinced either ways. So request your consent on the initial approach.

ghaskins
2016-10-12 23:35
The only part I don't agree with is I think the conditional could be replaced with a filespec

ghaskins
2016-10-12 23:36
E.g. "cat Dockerfile.in.$(ARCH)"

ghaskins
2016-10-12 23:36
Which I think is cleaner than a conditional, though the DRY implications are still a concern either way

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:38
so this would mean we rename existing http://Dockerfile.in to Dockerfile.in.x86_64 and have 2 more files (with same content) as Dockerfile.in.s390x and Dockerfile.in.ppc64le ?

cbf
2016-10-12 23:42
power and z already on 16.04?

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:42
yes

cbf
2016-10-12 23:43
are these IBM base images?

cbf
2016-10-12 23:43
I thought that the 16.04 and go1.7 changes were pending

cbf
2016-10-12 23:43
@ghaskins ?

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:43
these are hyperledger/fabric-baseimage

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:45
excerpt from fabric/images/base/Makefile ```DOCKER_BASE_x86_64=ubuntu:trusty DOCKER_BASE_s390x=s390x/ubuntu:xenial DOCKER_BASE_ppc64le=ppc64le/ubuntu:xenial```

cbf
2016-10-12 23:49
did not realize that thanks

cbf
2016-10-12 23:49
even more reason to have arch specific builds

cbf
2016-10-12 23:50
so yes, copy the http://Dockerfile.in and tweak the power one

srirama_sharma
2016-10-12 23:51

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:35
@ry: for reasons that are still unclear, the vagrant build in the pipeline is very unreliable

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:35
though the most recent one appears to be a problem in the protobuf UTs

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:35
so probably a protobuf bug…but that said, its generally unreliable and its typically at the infrastructure level

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:35
not sure what we can do about it, but FYI

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:36
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/1471/

yacovm
2016-10-19 12:44
is it possible to get the "not-most-recent-one" instead? I don't remember it happened before

ghaskins
2016-10-19 12:59
well, the rub here is that the Z team needs v3.1.0

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:00
so, i can go back to v3.0.2 but that leaves Z out in the cold and its not a good long term strategy probably

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:00
i am contemplating switching the x86 build to use the binaries they provide though

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:00
that would mitigate some of the problems, at least for x86

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:00
i kicked off a new build, lets see if that was a fluke

yacovm
2016-10-19 13:02
isn't it possible to use 3.1.0 only for Z and 3.0.2 for the x86?

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:20
it is, but I really would only want to do that as a last resort

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:20
and really, if v3.1.0 has flaky UTs, they will be flaky on Z most likely

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:21
but, the CI environment for building vagrant has been notoriously unstable, the protobuf UTs might just be a victim

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:21
do you have any objection to v3.1.0 other than that last failure being concerning?

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:21
(as an example, an earlier run died inside an SSH)

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:22
so, I kind of suspect the platform is just not reliable, not so much the software running inside it

ghaskins
2016-10-19 13:22
(by “platform” i mean the CI backend that supports building vagrant)

yacovm
2016-10-19 13:39
I don't have any objections to anything as long as I get to push my code with the gRPC+Proto vendor folders of master :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:14
ok, that work is being done on CR 1839 and discussed in the #fabric-reconcile channel

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:14
1471 is more about upgrading the tooling

ry
2016-10-19 14:25

ry
2016-10-19 14:25

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:29

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:29

ry
2016-10-19 14:29

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:29

2016-10-19 14:32

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:32

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:33
took 26m on this build: https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-baseimage-verify-vagrant-x86_64/40/consoleFull

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:33
my only concern with the previous approach is it looked fragile

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:33
would be better if this could be tied into something more robust, like a nexus coordinate or a squid proxy

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:33
but ill leave that to you

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:34
if you are willing to support it, thats good enough for me

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:38
@ry: this is probably the most common failure I see

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:38
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-baseimage-verify-vagrant-x86_64/38/console

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:38
though I see others too, seemingly random failures in tools that should be robust, like ssh

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:38
so I somewhat suspect the execution environment for the vagrant vm its running is not robust

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:39
not sure what can be done about it, but JFYI

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:40
heres a wacky one: https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-baseimage-verify-vagrant-x86_64/31/console

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:41
another

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:41
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-baseimage-verify-vagrant-x86_64/26/console

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:41
its like the VM has heartburn from time to time

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:42
if this continues, perhaps we should temporarily disable the -vagrant targets…ill continue to produce those manually/locally

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:42
the docker targets are the ones that are really difficult for me anyway

ghaskins
2016-10-19 14:42

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:27
@ry: ping

ry
2016-10-21 20:30
@ghaskins: yes sir?

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:31
i see a potential storm on the horizon related to the current disconnect we have between what runs the CI processes and what we use elsewhere such as devenv

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:31
and I am wondering if we can address that by unifying them more

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:31
heres an example: @kostas has been waiting for the golang v1.7 update for a while, presumably so he can use some of the new facilities

kostas
2016-10-21 20:32
has joined #ci-pipeline

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:32
i am on the verge of having this support available via the baseimage v0.2.0 activity

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:32
however, if he were to then code a change in fabric.git, it might not compile in Jenkins without further action on your part

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:33
and then there is the issue of, we could simply upgrade jenkins to 1.7, but what implications might that have for older fabric.git

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:34
what I am wondering is: is there a way we can structure infra so that there is a tigher relationship with the CI “baseimage” similar to how we have a coupling to the vagrant and docker baseimages

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:34
few different thoughts: we could have a third output of baseimage.git (say, OVS) that is used by jenkins

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:35
another idea: we could run the tests inside docker

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:35
(since we already have docker baseimage)

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:35
third idea: there are integrations to run jenkins jobs inside vagrant, so that could use the existing vagrant baseimage

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:35
im open to other ideas as well, of course

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:35
those are just to get the conversation started

ry
2016-10-21 20:36
I'm open to the easiest way forward that doesn't hamstring us later

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:36
to me: the docker model seems like the lightest weight path forward on several fronts

ry
2016-10-21 20:36
Since we have docker base images and can build ... yes

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:36
for one, we already publish it

ry
2016-10-21 20:36
I agree

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:36
and second, its the lightest weight option

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:37
(in terms of VM overhead)

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:37
ok, well lets use that as the operational model for a POC until we find we cant or have a better idea

ry
2016-10-21 20:41
Agreed

ry
2016-10-21 20:45
We could probably, if required, set up a second type of builder using a different image (go 1.7)

ry
2016-10-21 20:45
It might be easier to have specific builds go to specific classes of builders

ry
2016-10-21 20:46
And avoid new docker builds

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:46
Yes, though I am inclined to try to stick it under baseimage since it basically already captures the dependency

ry
2016-10-21 20:47
OK

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:47
We could have the Jenkins job just read .baseimage-release, and then boot stage 2 inside that

ghaskins
2016-10-21 20:50
ill play around in the sandbox

ry
2016-10-21 21:19
looking at vagrant in ci-management, we’re currently building `docker pull hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:x86_64-0.0.10`

ry
2016-10-21 21:20
no reason that couldn’t be re-run as the first line of build

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:23
right, and then we just need to adapt what happens next in the context of a docker-run

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:23
the bigger challenge will likely be trying to get UTs to run inside a docker container

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:23
(or maybe not, who knows

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:23
but that is where I expect the most friction

ry
2016-10-21 21:24
aren’t we sort-of doing that already?

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:24
well, we launch docker processes, but we dont do the actual build inside them

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:24
at least, not in the same way we do it outside

ry
2016-10-21 21:24
ah OK.

ghaskins
2016-10-21 21:25
i think its all doable, it just might require some tweaking

ry
2016-10-21 21:43
@garisingh Jenkins is now using Node 6.9.1

ry
2016-10-21 21:44
sorry it took so long

ry

cbf
2016-10-23 17:05
@ramesh why are we creating a http://hyperledger.github.io repo? We have http://hyperledger.org and IMO, having all these pages will only dilute our brand

cbf
2016-10-23 17:05
What is the intention? Is this to host docs generated from our SDKs?

cbf
2016-10-23 17:09
@ghaskins I tend to think that with Docker support for Mac and Windows, that vagrant has outlived its usefulness especially since we now have a base image. I think that we should start to encourage a docker-based approach to development - just mounting the source tree into the container and having ‘make images unit-tests behave’ as the default command.

ghaskins
2016-10-23 17:20
@cbf I agree

ghaskins
2016-10-23 17:20
i will begin looking into this

ghaskins
2016-10-23 17:20
(the Docker-on-mac support is quite good)

ghaskins
2016-10-23 17:21
it will improve a bunch of peripheral things too, like we can have the CI use the same flow

ghaskins
2016-10-23 17:22
(e.g. today CI and vagrant are maintained separately)

yacovm
2016-10-23 17:40
but we have more than docker stuff, we also have shell scripts. what are we going to do with them if we ditch the vagrant image?

ry
2016-10-23 17:47
@cbf @ghaskins @ramesh http://github.io repo deleted

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:15
I still need to conduct a study, but I think it can work @yacovm

cbf
2016-10-23 18:29
@yacovm I am thinking we use Docker for our build environment… not sure I follow the comment about shell scripts

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:30
you expect a developer to develop in windows, right?

cbf
2016-10-23 18:30
sure

cbf
2016-10-23 18:30
Docker runs natively on window

cbf
2016-10-23 18:30
Windows

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:30

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:30

cbf
2016-10-23 18:31
but we are developing not to run fabric natively, but to run containerized as we are presently

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:31

cbf
2016-10-23 18:31
I am merely suggesting that instead of creating a vagrant environment that we use Docker

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:32
I understand, all I'm saying there are some corner cases such as this one

cbf
2016-10-23 18:32
instead of ‘vagrant up; vagrant ssh’ we can simply run a docker-compose that binds the local clone of fabric into a container that has all the same content as the vagrant image

cbf
2016-10-23 18:33
if you are compiling on Windows, then you don’t need docker

cbf
2016-10-23 18:34
same for Mac or Z for that matter

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:34
how can I compile the proto files, if the script that compiles them is a shell script? I'll have to install cygwin or something for that.

cbf
2016-10-23 18:34
the whole point of vagrant was to have a portable vm in which you can do development/builds

cbf
2016-10-23 18:35
@yacovm I’m struggling with your concern… I am speaking purely of replacing vagrant with docker

cbf
2016-10-23 18:35
aside from that nothing changes

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:36
oh, I see

yacovm
2016-10-23 18:36
the "make" for example will write to a shared volume mounted by docker with write access?

cbf
2016-10-23 18:36
correct

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:41
That's how I see it too

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:41
Today we use vagrant to normalize things like the compiler and libs

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:42
We can use docker for that instead

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:44
So, if you have an environment that has commands like git, make, and docker, you can run a build to produce docker artifacts like fabric-peer

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:45
@cbf I also plan on investigating splitting up the build from the runtime

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:46
So the runtime image doesn't need all the baggage, just the peer binary, core.yaml, and things like that

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:46
Migrating to alpine eventually ;)

ghaskins
2016-10-23 18:46
But baby steps...

cbf
2016-10-23 18:55
Agree, there’s a lot of baggage in build not needed for runtime

garisingh
2016-10-23 23:04
@ghaskins - let me know if you'd like to split the task for the runtime piece. I've done a lot of work in making smaller runtime Docker images in the past. Do we feel we have any limitations in terms of our options here? Also - if we remove the REST API in v1.0 from the peer (at least the transactional piece), I believe that we can remove the Go compiler from the peer image and certainly not needed in the membersrvc / cop (v1) image either

mtakemiya
2016-10-25 11:44
It’s a ci platform, like jenkins or travis.

mtakemiya
2016-10-25 11:44
From our experience, it seems to be the fastest and one of the easiest to use.

mtakemiya
2016-10-25 11:45
It costs money usually, but is free for open source projects.

2016-10-25 12:08

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:05
@vpaprots has, for the most part, mitigated the issue for now, but it would be highly desirable to get it fixed rather than worked around

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:06
understand

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:06
the issue is it cannot run the “chaintool” binary

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:06
one small step at a time

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:06
right

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:06
workaround is you can explicitly launch it with “java -jar chaintool"

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:06
yes

vpaprots
2016-10-26 18:06
@harrijk @ramesh flying back to toronto.. on the tarmac now, sorry for the slow responses last couple of days

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:07
i think binfmts is setup to issue java -jar for openjdk on ubuntu (??)

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:07
nbd for now, just wanted to make sure you were both aware that selecting ibmjava has a potential problem

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:09
yes, i think one of the proposed changes was to update car/package.go

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:09
buf = append(buf, fmt.Sprintf("RUN java -jar /usr/local/bin/chaintool buildcar /tmp/package.car -o $GOPATH/bin/%s && rm /tmp/package.car", spec.ChaincodeID.Name))

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:09
another time, another change

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:09
yeah, i think that went in actually

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:09
but thats just a bandaid

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:09
oh really

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:10
if someone tries to work with chaintool on a platform with ibmjava, they are likely to be annoyed by that

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:10
how does openjdk get called when calling the chaintool executable?

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:10
binfmts?

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:10
or inherent in openjdk

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:11
in summary, I am using “lein-bin” (https://github.com/Raynes/lein-bin) which exploits a property of zip files that ignore data prior to the zip header

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:11
in this context, it emits a bash script as a preamble in front of the JAR

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:12
apparently this is a relatively widely known/supported trick, such that both maven and leiningen provide plugins to make self-executing java apps

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:12
and this cannot be done on s390x?

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:12
and openjdk/oracle-java support it, but ibmjava doesnt IFF you also use -Xbootclasspath

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:12
ok

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:13
just enough of a difference to cause headaches. :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:13
its not Z specifically, its a problem if you use preamble + -Xbootpath + ibmjava

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:13
ok

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:13
time for an advil, my head hurts. ha

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:13
heh

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:14
one potential solution is I can turn off -Xbootclasspath, but then the startup time noticeably declines in most environments

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:14
another option is I can fork/hack lein-bin to emit a preamble that checks for ibmjava and works around it

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:15
the best option would be if ibmjava worked the same as openjdk/oracle ;

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:15
:wink:

ghaskins
2016-10-26 18:15
but, that is admittedly also the easiest option for me

harrijk
2016-10-26 18:15
ha

2016-10-26 18:17

harrijk
2016-10-28 14:56
@srirama_sharma i tested the fabric-baseimage make docker-local command on my ppcle system. for the go installation, the GROOT environment variable that is being set in the setup.sh script (/usr/local/go) is being overridden by the ENV GOROOT=/opt/go statement in the http://Dockerfile.in file. This doesn't break anything as long as GOPATH is set correctly, but I just wanted to bring it to your attention. Perhaps this has been discussed before, if so, please disregard.

harrijk

2016-11-02 20:38

harrijk
2016-11-02 20:38

harrijk
2016-11-02 20:38

2016-11-02 20:38
right, we're coming in sideways though.

ry
2016-11-02 20:39

ry
2016-11-02 20:39
they just jump in and smash each other

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:02
basic flow for a release is: I push two patches (one that sets IS_RELEASE=true, and another that bumps the version and resets IS_RELEASE back to false

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:02
i see the jobs queued up in jenkins

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:03
ah ok

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:03
if the -verify jobs pass, and maintainers +2 it, the CRs go in

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:03
I then tag the CR that corresponds to the IS_RELEASE=true patch, and push that to gerrit

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:03
k. triggering release jobs

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:03
that sets the tag in both gerrit and GH ….AND should kick off the -release job

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:03
got it. cool. tnx

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:04
that last part has historically not worked however, so I would replace that last step with manual intervention

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:04
story of my life. :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:04
@ramesh tells me its primed and ready to go though, so we shall see

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:04
k

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:05
long story short, we have to wait for quite a few runs to complete before it will hit dockerhub

ramesh
2016-11-04 15:05
yes

ramesh
2016-11-04 15:05
will monitor

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:05
2x -verify, 2x -merge, and then 2x -release

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:05
ok. tnx for explanation

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:05
the process is not super efficient yet, but its improving and will continue to do so

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:06
i guess my next order of business to to look for a more elegant solution to the s390x javaenv docker image build issue.

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:06
this is still vast improvement over previous process, which involved me manually ssh;ing around and building these by hand

harrijk
2016-11-04 15:06

ghaskins
2016-11-04 15:07
assuming responsive merging of the patches by maintainers, I do expect the v0.2.1 release to hit dockerhub as early as today

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:10
@ry: I just pushed a WIP series, the last of which is here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2321/

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:10
it basically dockerizes the build/unit-tests (still need to address behave

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:10
but the biggest thing I am curious about is what version of docker-compose does CI include?

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:11
I am using a knob that is not supported in compose v1.5.2 (what we ship in devenv) but it does support it in v1.8.1 (the latest stable release)

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:11
so, depending on where CI sits, I may or may not work

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:11
I am expecting a degree of fireworks here, btw

ry
2016-11-07 16:12
I don't know off the top of my head, but I can look in a bit.

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:12
but, I think once it converges, things will generally be easier for both of us

ry
2016-11-07 16:12
"here" is this chain of changes, or "here" is this channel? :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:12
here is the chain of changes

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:13
2321 is the last of 17 patches in the series, IOW

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:13
(17 sounds like a lot, but quite a few of them are simple

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:13
theres only, id estimate, 3-4 that are real meaty

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:15
i generally ordered them as simple/less-controversial at the beginning, and the opposite at the end :wink:

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:16
anyway: the basis thesis is: make everything docker oriented and then the devenv/cienv/etc only need real basics to support a build/test run

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:17
2313 probably does the best job summarizing the effort: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2313/

ry
2016-11-07 16:30
@ry uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ry/F2YKR1DAM/-.txt

ry
2016-11-07 16:31
from https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/2412/console

ry
2016-11-07 16:31
do I need to update the CI images?

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:32
@ry: i guess theres a few questions to address

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:33
#1: will my proposal encapsulated in that series be accepted?

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:33
#2: are there any other ramifications for upgrading docker-compose

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:33
e.g. did someone specifically chose 1.5.2 for a reason?

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:34
if the answer to 2 is "doesnt matter", then updating CI to just bump to v1.8.1 and leaving everything else is a good mitigating strategy independent of the answer to #1

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:34
if #1 becomes a "yes", then at some point we may want to think about simplifying the cienv

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:35
because we no longer would need stuff like rocksdb, etc

ry
2016-11-07 16:41
nice

ry
2016-11-07 16:41
I'm all aboard the simple is better train

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:43
the ideal, minimal recipe for the cienv would then probably look not dissimilar to https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2321/1/devenv/setup.sh

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:44
i think the challenge with the simplification is we need the CI system to work with CRs that are both before and after the merge of the new design

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:44
(therein lies the challenge)

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:45
though I hope with this work, we can really start to decouple things like devenv/cienv from caring

ghaskins
2016-11-07 16:45
if ci only needs to provide a stable docker interface, then everything else becomes an overlay defined by the fabric.git REV

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:01
@ry: these are coming up in multiple CRs https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/2417/console

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:01
looks systemic

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:01
(though perhaps I just dont understand the root cause)

ry
2016-11-07 17:02
looks like network turbulence at our hosting company

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:02
ok

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:12
so, related to all this: we really should discuss the architecture between ci-management and fabric.git

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:12
theres some flaws in the current architecture, the pains of which we are beginning to bear

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:13
for example: ci-management.git assumes "make membersrvc-image" is a valid target

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:13
which, as we are now seeing in two different CRs, may not always be true

ghaskins
2016-11-07 17:14
i think the .travis.xml model is probably closer to how this should be driven so that CI follows the target

ry
2016-11-07 17:32
I'm OK with that. CI is here to serve the project.

2016-11-07 17:41

2016-11-08 01:44

ry
2016-11-08 01:45
when we have more than some number of builds (I think the number is 25) in the queue, we are just about guaranteed that a minion will be reused.

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:45
ah

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:45
so there is some kind of filesystem contention or something?

ry
2016-11-08 01:45
and our whole theory is that minions are single use only.

ry
2016-11-08 01:45
yes, one build isn't totally completely gone when the next one kicks off.

2016-11-08 01:45
i see

ry

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:57

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:57

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:57
e.g. we can somehow dispatch more than 25, but cant run more than 25 concurrently?

ry
2016-11-08 01:58
right

ry
2016-11-08 01:58
we can dispatch _n_ for some very large _n_

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:58

ghaskins
2016-11-08 01:58

2016-11-08 02:01

ry
2016-11-08 02:02
if the dispatcher is dribbling out builds once there is an available slot, I suppose that might be OK

ry
2016-11-08 02:03

ry

ghaskins
2016-11-11 20:06
on a positive note: @ry and I finally figured out why docker v1.12 was having problems with network access within the CI infra

ghaskins
2016-11-11 20:07
should have images available for testing TBD, but we at least have a handle on the issue

ry
2016-11-11 20:07
and that issue is around 108 bytes

ghaskins
2016-11-11 20:12
heh, yeah, @ry is alluding to the problem being related to default docker bridge MTU of 1500 bytes being 108 bytes too large for the IAAS provider that runs our infra

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:41
hey, I have 2 simple yet critical questions: 1) Each jenkins build runs in its own container, right? 2) Are some directories mounted and somehow shared between different instances?

ry
2016-11-17 21:43
1 no, we use VMs once, not containers - unless the build itself uses containers

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:43
Each build has it own VM?

ry
2016-11-17 21:43
2 not for minions, they're deleted after one use

ry
2016-11-17 21:43
Yes

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:43
what's minions?

ry
2016-11-17 21:44
It is possible that two build run on one minion (vm) under high load but rare

ry
2016-11-17 21:44
Minion is a more PC name for build slaves

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:44
so there is no chance that 2 builds somehow share a FS, right?

ry
2016-11-17 21:44
Think of the movie, uh, Minions :blush::blush:

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:46
?

ry
2016-11-17 21:47
under times ofhigh load - if the build queue exceeds 25 (iirc, maybe 32) it is possible that a minion would be reused, but so far that has been rare

ry
2016-11-17 21:48
I have a fix for that to ensure every minion is used once and only once but it would require a short outage to implement, so I'm waiting to roll up a bunch of infra needs before doing that

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:50
I see. Thanks for the clarification.

ry
2016-11-17 21:50
do you have a specific build you could point me to?

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:56
I'm asking for @c0rwin :wink:

yacovm
2016-11-17 21:56
He told me today that he suspects something but I wanted to make sure

ry
2016-11-17 21:57
I think @c0rwin, @ghaskins and I are having that conversation in DM :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:25
@c0rwin the cobertura report failure is a red herring

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:26
the actual failure was just above that, in the gossip UT

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:26
In this case, the offending test was: FAIL http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/gossip/state 15.341s

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:27
that said, it seems like the error did not propagate properly such that the cobertura portion was still trying to locate the report

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:29
@harrijk There seems to be something wrong with the s390x CI engine

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:30
https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-baseimage-verify-docker-s390x/7/console

c0rwin
2016-11-28 13:30
So cobertura tries to build up the report, while there is a test failure hence no report generated, as a consequence IOException… am I getting it right?

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:30
@harrijk: reference https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2795/1

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:31
@c0rwin yes, that seems to be the case...whats supposed to happen is the UTs run, piping their output into gocov-xml which generates report.xml

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:31
a UT then fails, which should stop the whole pipeline

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:31
but instead, the next phase which tries to process the report.xml still runs

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:31
so, the real problem is that a UT failed

c0rwin
2016-11-28 13:31
Oh, I see thanks

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:31
but a secondary problem is that the UT failure was not detected

c0rwin
2016-11-28 13:32
will take a look into UT

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:34
@ramesh can you investigate the secondary problem mentioned above?

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:35
Not sure where the disconnect is occuring, but the UT fail should have propagated in a way that you don't try to process the report

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:35
(it could be my fault/problem, to be clear)

ghaskins
2016-11-28 13:35
but if you can investigate it, that would be helpful

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:20
note that the output is emitted from the peer, not the UT

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:20
does that make sense?

2016-11-29 13:38

@yacovm does that still imply some kind of ordering violation occurred?

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:51

ghaskins

On a related note, I have an outstanding CR that suppresses the "vp_1" output

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:52

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:52
e.g. is that output actually useful?

ghaskins
2016-11-29 13:52
https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/2805/

yacovm
2016-11-29 13:54
1) we have no use of the external peer's logging. I'd assume it might(?) be useful for other squads 2) @c0rwin said an hour ago he'll make a PR that sets the default gossip/state logging level to something above DEBUG so it wouldn't output these stuff in the peer UT.

ghaskins
2016-11-29 14:02
ok, the rationale of 2805 is that we historically have suppressed this output anyway

ghaskins
2016-11-29 14:02
it was only recently exposed when I switched the UTs to use docker

ghaskins
2016-11-29 14:03
my understanding is that the peer is only used peripherally in 1-2 tests, not generally

ghaskins
2016-11-29 14:03
I am not sure what would have driven vp_1 to output those messages in this case, but my guess is it was coincidental to the UT activity

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:27
@ry is it possible to setup a new release build job for V0.6 release build for Power? Previously @ramesh setup baseimage job at https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/view/fabric-baseimage/job/fabric-baseimage-release-docker-ppc64le/

ry
2016-12-05 19:39
bsmita: the repo is public, you're welcome to submit revisions

ry
2016-12-05 19:39
bsmita: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/admin/projects/ci-management add me as a reviewer

ry
2016-12-05 19:40
when you have a change

ry
2016-12-05 19:40
be sure to loop in @ghaskins as well

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:40
I am not sure how new requests for builds are done, but is there a sample I can look at?

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:41
We don't need baseimage build now, but the build is for peer/membersrvc images

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:45
@bsmita "normally" (I say in quotes since this is new plumbing), the -release job runs in response to a maintainer (namely, me) pushing a new git tag to gerrit

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:46
a typical flow would be someone, presumably me, submits a dual CR: one that sets IS_RELEASE true, and a second one that resets it back to false along with a bump in the version

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:46
it gets voted on: assuming it accumulates at least 2+2 it gets merge

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:46
I then create an annotated tag against the commit from the first CR, and push it to gerrit

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:47
this triggers jenkins to run the -release job, which, like -verify and -merge will do a full build

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:47
the main difference is, this is against the git-tag

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:47
if it succeeds, the job also pushes the images out to dockerhub

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:47
Ok...the job has to be present in the list right?

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:48
since v0.6.1-preview already went through this process (with only x86_64 online) there isnt a natural mechanism to back-release against the same tag

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:48
so, assuming the back-release is agreed upon, there are a few options

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:49
we could cut a new v0.6 release (like I mentioned, we kind of need to anyway since there are fixes in the branch that didnt make it into v0.6.1)

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:49
we could manually trigger the missing builds against the v0.6.1-tag

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:49
we could build/push them by hand

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:49
im sure there are other options or variations of those same themes

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:50
but the main point is: there isnt a turn-key process to accommodate your request: v0.6.1 was already cut

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:51
OK..can we do V0.6.2? Along with x86?

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:51
I am in favor of this

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:51
OK..

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:52
Please let me know if I need to do anything for the new release build

ghaskins
2016-12-05 19:55
are the P builders in Jenkins primed and ready?

bsmita
2016-12-05 19:56
The nodes are online, I tried few builds late last week which worked, not sure what needs to be done to cleanup

harrijk
2016-12-05 21:49
@jonathanlevi since the behave tests are currently disabled/worked around in the fabric build CI process, the following information is not a high priority: the kafka behave tests utilize x86 docker images ( openjdk:8u111-jre and zookeeper:3.4.9 ) to build the kafka environment. Both p and z will not be able to run these behave tests. perhaps down the road, we could incorporate kafka and zookeeper into the fabric-baseimage build process. just a thought.

2016-12-05 23:38

2016-12-08 13:24
@ry, @srirama_sharma note that we can't turn on those P/Z jobs until the CR that updates baseimage to v0.2.2 is merged

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:24
(IIUC)

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 13:24
@ghaskins Yes. you are right

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:25

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:25

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:25
suggest making P/Z an advisory vote during the transition

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:26
once everyone is rebased on top of the v0.2.2 cut-point, we can enable full vote

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 13:28
Sounds okay to me. With the advisory vote, even if the verify jobs fail, we will know why it is failing - either requiring a rebase or due to any other issue due to arch difference.

ghaskins
2016-12-08 13:35
right, and then once we stablize things so X/P/Z are expected to collectively pass, we can turn on the verification to ensure it continues to be that way moving forward

harrijk
2016-12-08 13:36
@ramesh experiencing unit-test failures for p and z is a good sign in terms on ensuring that the codebase works for all platforms. When the unit-tests were disabled, p and z were in "catch up" mode (putting in patches to resolved platform-based issues) in an attempt to get to a point where the unit-tests could then be re-enabled. i can somewhat understand disabling due to lack of minions... if this is the case then how many minions are required?

harrijk
2016-12-08 13:39
i will write up a jira issue on the latest issue re; errors unit-test failing for p and z. if i checkout the commit before the error framework commit was put in, all tests pass. when i checkout the error framework commit, the errors test fails. root@p880-lpar7:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git checkout ae9f2f2 ae9f2f2 [FAB-816] Clean multichain integration interfaces ===> PASS root@p880-lpar7:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git checkout 2dc82e0 2dc82e0 Enhance and begin using error handling framework ===> FAIL

harrijk

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 14:45
@ghaskins the ppc64le base image with tag - ppc64le-0.0.11 that was pushed few days back to https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-baseimage/ is having issues. It is missing out all the rocksdb header files. Hence with this docker image, fabric build from v0.6 branch is failing now. Build works fine if I force a latest baseimage build from source by editing `images/base/release` to 0.0.12. ``` root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:ppc64le-0.0.11 root@51db3bf8e72b:/# find / -name rocksdb root@51db3bf8e72b:/# root@51db3bf8e72b:/# exit exit root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git status On branch v0.6 Your branch is up-to-date with 'origin/v0.6'. Changes not staged for commit: (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed) (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory) modified: images/base/release Untracked files: (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed) nohup.out no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a") root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# git diff diff --git a/images/base/release b/images/base/release index 2cfabea..8cbf02c 100644 --- a/images/base/release +++ b/images/base/release @@ -1 +1 @@ -0.0.11 +0.0.12 root@p006vm40:~/git/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric# docker run -it hyperledger/fabric-baseimage:latest root@766aa88cfb29:/# find / -name rocksdb /usr/local/include/rocksdb root@766aa88cfb29:/# ls /usr/local/include/rocksdb/ c.h db.h flush_block_policy.h memtablerep.h rate_limiter.h statistics.h types.h cache.h db_dump_tool.h immutable_options.h merge_operator.h slice.h status.h universal_compaction.h compaction_filter.h delete_scheduler.h iostats_context.h metadata.h slice_transform.h table.h utilities compaction_job_stats.h env.h iterator.h options.h snapshot.h table_properties.h version.h comparator.h experimental.h ldb_tool.h perf_context.h sst_dump_tool.h thread_status.h write_batch.h convenience.h filter_policy.h listener.h perf_level.h sst_file_writer.h transaction_log.h write_batch_base.h root@766aa88cfb29:/# ```

2016-12-08 15:18

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:22

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:23
so, no tag exists, but a commit-sha should

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:23

ghaskins

?

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:27
for v0.6, this is in images/base

2016-12-08 15:28

2016-12-08 15:28

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:29

ghaskins
2016-12-08 15:30

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:18

2016-12-08 16:18
https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-peer/tags/

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:19
technically, the :latest tag that is there is totally bogus, but there are flows that are still dependent on it being there

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:19
(as I discovered when I tried to clean this up and people complained

bsmita
2016-12-08 16:19
Ok...

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:19
so, I put it back, pointing to x86_64-0.6.1-preview for now

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:20
obviously, I can only do this once :wink:

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:20
I can put ppc64le-0.6.1-preview out there, but I cant retag it :latest

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:21
you would have to qualify whether this even works and what work-arounds you might need to recommend to people to deal with

bsmita
2016-12-08 16:21
I think for now we can work with this tag

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:22
ppc64le-0.6.1 should be okay for now for both peer and membersrvc

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:23
ok, let me think about best way to get it out there

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:23
we may need an additional step of pulling ppc64le-0.6.1 and then tagging it locally to :latest

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:24
yes...you still need to keep in mind: the code still is not structured to work with pure dockerhub yet

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:24
even in mainline, technically

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:25
see FAB-678

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:25
you mean different repo for different arch making use of the way docker understands the arch ?

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:25
ok.

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:25
right now, even mainline, the only thing that "works" is building from source

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:26
though it is slightly easier to deal with in mainline, and is converging on totally turn key as part of FAB-678

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:26
we have docker compose scripts locally to pull the images with right tag based on the underlying arch

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:26
right, but that alone might not be enough

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:27
the issue is that in v0.6 and earlier, the build synthesizes baseimage:latest in a JIT fashion as part of the build

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:27
its not just a retagging, it also processes the image locally

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:27
Oh. ok

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:27
that synthesis would not occur if you simply "docker run hyperledger/fabric-peer:ppc64le-..."

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:28
the long and the short of it is: the images such as peer and membersrvc were pushed to dockerhub before the code was really ready to use that model

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:29
and then people started to rely on them being there, making it a tough situation

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:29
this is improving on several fronts, at least in master, but we arent quite there to call FAB-678 "done"

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:30
for one, the code will auto-couple versions

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:30
and for seconds, the baseimage no longer requires synthesis

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:31
there is still a gaping hole on the SDK front, but if I can ever get out from under my build/release duties, ill fix :wink:

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:31
yeah. I think I get it .. and hence the BASE_TAG being used right ?

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:31
precisely, that is the auto-couple thing

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:31
like, peer vX.Y.Z will couple to ccenv vX.Y.Z

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:32
ok

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:32
long story short: we _can_ push those tags to dockerhub, but I am not entirely sure what it buys us really

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:33
my recommendation, anyone working in v0.6 should be building from source...its really the only supported deployment model

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:33
at least now, we have build-caches for P/Z :wink:

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:34
rejoice in not needing to wait for rocksdb or protoc to compile any more :wink:

srirama_sharma
2016-12-08 16:34
yeah. Thats quite a relief and save of time

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:34
so, all that said: if you guys really want those images up there, I have no problem with it

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:34
just not sure what it really buys us

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:35
I dont want my statements to be misconstrued as refusing to publish, that is not the case at all

bsmita
2016-12-08 16:36
If it's not too much trouble please push them, we are just making sure that the end to end build process is working and we have a version of docker images available for Power also :slightly_smiling_face:

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:36
ok, ill have to check but I dont think we have anything automated for v0.6

ghaskins
2016-12-08 16:37
I think all v0.6/v0.0.11 artifacts were done either manually or via jenkins sandbox

bsmita
2016-12-08 16:37
Ok..thank you!

kostas
2016-12-14 20:23
Can someone help me figure out why this build (and those that depend on it) keep failing in CI? https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3201/

ry
2016-12-14 20:25
kostas the log file is pretty clear. there was a change checked in which has broken the unit tests.

ry
2016-12-14 20:26
@ry uploaded a file: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/ry/F3F0A5JQM/-.txt

kostas
2016-12-14 20:28
@ry: The interesting this is though -- based on our conversation earlier today, I tracked the culprit, had Marko submit a changeset and that fixed it: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3305/

kostas
2016-12-14 20:28
Notice how the build for this ^^ was successful.

kostas
2016-12-14 20:28
Now, I did `reverify` after this one got merged. And I'm still getting a failure.

ry
2016-12-14 20:28
kostas you will need to rebase to pick up his change. It is in the future for your change

ry
2016-12-14 20:30
you should see a "rebase" button here: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3201/

kostas
2016-12-14 20:30
OK, do you suggest `rebase` via the button, or do it the way our ancestors did, by creating a new branch off of the latest master and cherry-picking my commit on top of it?

ry
2016-12-14 20:31
I'm a tool-using ape. I use the `rebase` button.

kostas
2016-12-14 20:31
Gotcha, thank you.

ry
2016-12-14 20:31
you will then need to, of course, run through all the child changes and do the same

ry
2016-12-14 20:32
I'm interested to see what happens when you get ~7 commits down the line

ry
2016-12-14 20:35
kostas if you really wanted to, you could `git checkout master; git pull origin master` then checkout the childmost change and do a `git rebase -i origin/master` to rebase them all at once. then `git push origin HEAD:refs/for/master` and all the changesets would be done in one swell foop without creating another branch etc

harrijk
2016-12-14 20:45
git guru :slightly_smiling_face:

kostas
2016-12-14 21:03
I can reproduce this locally now, which is something.

ry
2016-12-14 21:11

ghaskins
2016-12-14 22:55
more than likely, you will find the peer cannot run

kostas
2016-12-15 00:10
Greg, I don't see an `ORDERER_CFG_PATH` ENV var in `unittest_vp_1`.

kostas
2016-12-15 00:10
```"Env": [ "PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/local/bin", "PEER_CFG_PATH=/etc/hyperledger/fabric" ],```

kostas
2016-12-15 00:10
Any idea what might cause this?

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:10
"vp" -> fabric-peer != fabric-orderer :wink:

kostas
2016-12-15 00:11
Heh, makes sense. This is actually me trying to fix this: https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-peer-dev/p1481648308000066

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:11
to put another way: the unit tests do not currently start the orderer

kostas
2016-12-15 00:11
I'll put in a fix for this, I noted that cross-dependencies are a bad idea.

kostas
2016-12-15 00:11
Thank you.

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:12
this is primarily a function of the fact that historically the unit tests have only minimal interaction with the running peer

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:12
e.g. they do not need a fully functioning peer environment

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:12
that said, I have thought it was perhaps asking for trouble to purposely only instantiate a partial environment

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:13
if you believe that the orderer should be running, I have no problem with this: just update unit-test/docker-compose.yml as appropriate

kostas
2016-12-15 00:14
If I'm reading this properly, it is simply an issue of setting the ENV var on fabric-peer and maybe copying the orderer.yaml file as well?

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:14
you can probably borrow from test/docker-compose.yml, if that is convenient

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:15
just take a look at the ./test composition, i think it has all the details

ry
2016-12-15 00:15

2016-12-15 00:15
@ry: ok, ty

ry
2016-12-15 00:15

ry
2016-12-15 00:16
``

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:16
@kostas are you thinking we want to run both peer and orderer in vp_1 instance?

kostas
2016-12-15 00:18
@ghaskins: No. Reading this https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/archives/fabric-peer-dev/p1481648503000069 my understanding is that the peer _temporarily_ (I hope) needs the genesis block that the bootstrapper (a package in the orderer) gives.

kostas
2016-12-15 00:18
But the bootstrapper needs to read the `orderer.yaml` file before it can output a block with my latest changeset.

kostas
2016-12-15 00:18
So that's what's causing the issue.

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:18
oh...that sounds broken, but I assume that is what you are referring to when you say you hope its temporary

kostas
2016-12-15 00:18
In short, all we need to do is get the fabric peer to see that `orderer.yaml` file.

kostas
2016-12-15 00:19
Exactly.

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:19
ok...the problem is the fabric-peer container will only have the bare minimum of what it thinks is needed

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:19
which, right at this moment, would not include orderer.yaml

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:19
so the ENV alone wont do it

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:19
it would be trivial to make it so it does have it though

ghaskins
2016-12-15 00:20
I could put a patch together in short order to do this, but I wouldnt be doing my maintainer duty if I didn't ask if we should just fix the root cause first? :wink:

kostas
2016-12-15 00:21

2016-12-15 00:21

ghaskins

ghaskins

2016-12-16 17:13

cbf
2016-12-16 17:13
I ask because we start to think about re-introducing integration testing, we need to treat the various components as fixed dependencies

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:14

cbf
2016-12-16 17:14
that we bump as we establish stability

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:14
yeah, as in $build-no as opposed to $release

cbf
2016-12-16 17:14
yes

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:14
yes, would also be good to try to optimize the pipeline

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:15
build once, then verify -> release or whatever

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:15
instead of build over and over again

cbf
2016-12-16 17:15
we definitely need to do this, also for more long running tests etc which we probably don't want to saddle with a build as well

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:15

ghaskins
2016-12-16 17:15

2016-12-20 16:27

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:27

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:27
Make can sometimes be funny with wildcard rules (of which, build/docker/bin/% is one)

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:27
so if someone made a well intentioned mod to the Makefile, it can sometimes inadvertently break wildcards in unexpected ways

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:27
thats the only thing I can think of

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:28
if it happens again, dont make any changes and ping me

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:28
we can run "make -d" etc to try to see whats happening

ry
2016-12-20 16:31
@ghaskins Nexus 2.x doesn't function as a dockerhub write through cache. Nexus 3.0 will, but we aren't rolling 3.x out because (a) the pro version isn't out yet (b) it lost some features we use. However. I've set up the permission groups for fabric and fabric-baseimage and I'm looking at how other projects we support use nexus

ry
2016-12-20 16:31
that doesn't mean we can't push docker artifacts to nexus, it just doesn't have the write through cache we were discussing

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:31
@ry: ok, we have a few options

c0rwin
2016-12-20 16:31
@ghaskins sure, I'm going to re-iterate everything once again to see whenever it re-occurs again

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:31
@c0rwin ok, cool, ty

ry
2016-12-20 16:31
@ghaskins hit me

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:32
@ry: can you clarify what the write-through option means in this context?

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:32
does that mean it can transparently push to dockerhub too?

ry
2016-12-20 16:32
instead of publishing directly to dockerhub, my understanding was... yes. we would publish to nexus which would then publish to dockerhub.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:32
im not sure we actually need or even want that

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:33
im thinking in this context, we primarily care about an intermediate/local repo, so 2.x may be sufficient

ry
2016-12-20 16:33
and if there is a better project other than fabric or fabric-baseimage to start on, let me know.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:33
it might be interesting to make the final -release stage take advantage of a write-through cache, but I see that as more of an optimization than a functional requirement

ry
2016-12-20 16:33
ok

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:34
what would be awesome is introducing a local repo so that we can pipeline build -> ut -> at -> release without rebuilding everything

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:34
it sounds like nexus 2.x would fit those requirements as it is

ry
2016-12-20 16:35
OK. does that imply the earlier discussion of breaking the build into _n_ steps?

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:36
well, I see that as the end-game, but we dont need it broken up to take advantage here

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:36
it could just be build -> [test the world] -> release

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:36
where [test-the-world] is like our current -verify stage

ry
2016-12-20 16:36
OK, and release is the -merge job or similar

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:36
actually, baby step would be build -> [test-the-world]

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:37
(since we dont do automated releases yet

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:37
right

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:37
so build -> [-verify] and build -> [-merge] as a first step

ry
2016-12-20 16:38
should have said _write back_ cache

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:38
and then perhaps build -> [-verify-ut] -> [-verify-at] and build -> [-merge-ut] -> [-merge-at] -> [-release]

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:38
as a longer term plan

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:38
obviously only the "-merge" class pipeline should result in something releasing

ry
2016-12-20 16:39
so the merge job would not consume the artifacts of the first build step, but a new one, which makes sense since we seem to collect build breaks with merges right now

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:39
I have a feeling that the -at class stage would be some number of parallel jobs

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:39
exactly, that is my thought

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:40
the main point would be to front-end the pipeline with a artifact submitted to nexus rather than rebuilding each stage

ry
2016-12-20 16:40
when you say pipeline, do you literally mean the Jenkins pipeline feature?

ry
2016-12-20 16:40
which I'm fine with, I've just never used it and have no experience with it

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:40
but I think for the time being, it makes sense to consider the -verify and -merge pipelines orthogonal

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:41
well, im speaking generally as in "pipeline" = jenkins processing

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:41
but I do envision it would look close to jenkins pipeline plugin, if not literally

ry
2016-12-20 16:42
which project are we focusing on? fabric, fabric-baseimage, or something else?

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:42
I guess this makes sense to consider it fabric-*, at least IMO

ry
2016-12-20 16:42
I just want to make sure I understand everything before I start spelunking.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:42
but obviously we should focus in one place and then carry over lessons learned

ry
2016-12-20 16:43

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:43

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:43

ry
2016-12-20 16:44

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:44

ry
2016-12-20 16:45

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:46
cool, ill check it out

ry
2016-12-20 16:47
it looks like they have the unauthenticated "view configuration" button, which is good. they also have the ci repo public

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:47
but to your comment about mvn at the bottom, yes, this has been one of my thoughts too

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:47
I know you can basically submit any file as a maven coordinate

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:47
so it doesnt have to be "docker push" based, per se

ry
2016-12-20 16:47
that's what I suspect.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:47
not sure what would be the best design yet, we will have to play

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:48
I think the main requirements will be a) having an intermediate repo to hold build artifacts, whatever they may be, b) having those artifacts be addressable in a context specific way, c) having a decent expiration policy in place so we dont crush the repo with cruft over time

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:49
I suspect (a) and (b) are well handled with nexus because, they are well handled in maven/docker in general

ry
2016-12-20 16:49
that seems reasonable. esp with vagrant artifacts being so huge

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:49
(c) will be interesting to see if the nexus and/or jenkins folks have a good story there

ry
2016-12-20 16:50
I know (c) has been a battle elsewhere

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:50
yeah, its one of the reasons I was hesitant to push every build to dockerhub

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:50
heh

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:50
1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G-> 1.4G'

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:50
how long until they get PO'd

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:50
:wink:

ry
2016-12-20 16:51
I have been [awaiting, dreading] the call from dockerhub/vagrant/npm/redhat where they cut us off for directly using them for CI.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:51
the neat thing about the expiration policy is I think its more or less tied to the pipeline

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:52
e.g. the demarcation point for where the artifact is useful is tied 1:1 with pipeline completion

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:52
it either gets released or it doesnt

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:52
we can probably exploit that to make a reasonable policy

ry
2016-12-20 16:53
sure. we just need to come to consensus as to what reasonable is

ry
2016-12-20 16:54
I think you might keep some artifacts for failed passes around until unit tests are no longer flaky

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:57
right, that makes sense to me

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:58
so, the pipeline completion is one gate

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:58
some other policy, like 24hrs expiring could be the second

ry
2016-12-20 16:59
sure.

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:59
im sure it could even be more liberal than that and not be too onerous on the LF infra

ghaskins
2016-12-20 16:59
1 wk? who knows

ry
2016-12-20 17:00
Looking at https://jenkins.open-o.org/view/Merge-Jobs/job/ci-management-merge-packer-ubuntu-16.04-basebuild/configure for example, there is a huge script at the end to archive the log files but the meat of the job appears to be at the end: `clean deploy -V -B -q -Dmaven.repo.local=/tmp/r`

ry
2016-12-20 17:02
I'll outline a process other projects use, which we can shoot for someday: there are no manual merges. You really just tell Jenkins a change is a candidate for merge, and it does a rebase/rebuild/merge/publish loop. this does two nice things: no more broken merges and your commit log doesn't have 40 merge commits in a row

ry
2016-12-20 17:03
s/Jenkins/gerrit

harrijk
2016-12-21 16:20
@ghaskins re: voting for the p and z jobs... i believe you mentioned that they should be advisory votes until all CRs that aren't rebased on CR 3329 are integrated into the codebase... does this still hold true (i.e. advisory vote)

ghaskins
2016-12-21 16:21
@harrijk im not sure that was turned on

ghaskins
2016-12-21 16:21
@ramesh @ry: any comment?

ry
2016-12-21 16:23
they're disabled right now. there is a subtle issue with letting them vote in an advisory way - the way Jenkins works, it withholds all votes until everything has voted. this means P and in particular Z will be a huge bottleneck for CI.

ghaskins
2016-12-21 16:23
makes sense

harrijk
2016-12-21 16:24
huge bottleneck in terms of very few minions, i assume

ry
2016-12-21 16:24
which is fine - that's a price the project can choose to bear. I didn't want to enable anything (really, I don't want to make too many changes) right before I leave for 9 days

harrijk
2016-12-21 16:25
OK, let's tackle this in 10 days. :slightly_smiling_face:

harrijk
2016-12-21 16:26
p and z need to participate in verification, otherwise, it will be a never-ending job of catching up to resolve arch issues.

ghaskins

ghaskins
2016-12-27 14:21

2016-12-29 15:20

baohua
2017-01-03 07:51
has joined #ci-pipeline

baohua
2017-01-03 07:54
hi, anyone know how to let our dockerhub project automatically be triggered by commit merging, and building the image? Thanks to @ry ‘s help, we’ve created one docker hub repo at https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-py/, while the code repo is at https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-sdk-py.

baohua
2017-01-03 07:55
Thanks :slightly_smiling_face:

cbf
2017-01-03 13:43
@baohua take a look at the Makefile for the fabric project. We submit a CS that updates the IS_RELEASE variable to 'true' and that cuts a release and publishes the images to dockerhub.

cbf
2017-01-03 13:44
then we submit a follow-on CS that sets the IS_RELEASE value back to 'false' and update the release number accordingly

baohua
2017-01-03 13:44
thanks chrisfer, you mean the makefile in the fabric project?

cbf
2017-01-03 13:44
yes

baohua
2017-01-03 13:45
So we need to update that makefile to maintain the sdk image?

cbf
2017-01-03 13:45
yes

cbf
2017-01-03 13:45
makes it more formal

cbf
2017-01-03 13:45
but I think that is a good thing

cbf
2017-01-03 13:46
don't you also need to publish to pypy?

cbf
2017-01-03 13:47
oh, let me be clear

cbf
2017-01-03 13:47
you don't need to update fabric Makefile to publish sdk, you would adapt your Makefile (or build process) in a similar manner

cbf
2017-01-03 13:48
we will obviously need to work on coordination of what goes with what, etc

baohua
2017-01-03 13:48
ok, understand now. so the way is to manually upload the built image to dockerhub, instead of a auto-build.

baohua
2017-01-03 13:48
triggered by code change.

baohua
2017-01-03 13:48
Thanks for the advice, chris!

cbf
2017-01-03 13:48
well, no

cbf
2017-01-03 13:49
the code change is the revised Makefile (in the fabric case)

cbf
2017-01-03 13:49
the logic that uploads the new images triggers off that variable

baohua
2017-01-03 13:49
IMHO, the makefile way is to build the image locally and then upload the image to the dockerhub, right?

ramesh
2017-01-03 15:04
@baohua yes that is correct for fabric baseimages.. but peer, orderer, etc.. are build locally using make file and upload images to dockerhub through CI process https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/gitweb?p=ci-management.git;a=blob;f=jjb/releases/include-raw-fabric-app-image.sh;h=2841dcdf457dbe37a18189d3052160b3572e725b;hb=refs/heads/master

cbf
2017-01-03 15:07
@ramesh welcome back... so, I am mistaken? I thought we published when we cut a release from CI

ramesh
2017-01-03 15:10
you are right.. In both cases (fabric baseimages and application images process) we are depending on IS_RELEASE condition.. but building images and publishing to docker hub through makefile is applicable for fabric base images but for application images (peer , orderer ..)_ we are depending on CI to publish.. IS_RELEASE

ry
2017-01-04 16:59
I am aware of slowdowns in jenkins. there is an issue with our provider this morning and IO is slow right now. we're working with them to correct it.

cbf
2017-01-04 19:06
I was just exploring this myself

cbf
2017-01-04 19:06
the tests pass locally

cbf
2017-01-04 19:06
so there is something with jenkins or the network that is slowing things down and then causing the failure

ry
2017-01-04 19:07
there are two issues. One is a routing issue from our upstream provider which has been causing trouble today

ry
2017-01-04 19:08
the second issue is that there was an IO slowdown, and our provider put in a bunch more SSD to spread the IO out. Ceph is being re-arranged to take advantage of the new, higher IO capacity so we aren't out of the woods yet

ry
2017-01-04 19:08
the routing issue should have been solved by brute force: that route was dropped

srirama_sharma
2017-01-09 18:27
@ramesh my suggestion would be to add - verify and -merge as well for power platform

srirama_sharma
2017-01-09 18:29

srirama_sharma
2017-01-09 18:31
@ghaskins, so with this change, fabric-baseimage will then make use of these platform specific busybox images?

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:41
@srirama_sharma its actually somewhat orthogonal currently. At best, its the other way around

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:41
baseimage is the root for most things build-time (and currently, runtime for chaincode) whereas busybox is runtime

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:42
in genera, we use baseimage to build something, and then strip it down and stuff the result into a minimal container with busybox

srirama_sharma
2017-01-09 18:42
Oh. OK. Got it. And that would be used as runtime

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:43
the reason I mentioned it being "the other way around" is I actually use baseimage to compile busybox itself :wink:

srirama_sharma
2017-01-09 18:43
OK.

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:44
(see line 21: https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3761/5/docker-env.mk)

ghaskins
2017-01-09 18:44
that way, I can leverage all the X/P/Z work already done to get an $arch neutral compiler environment

ry
2017-01-10 20:17
right now our provider has a mix of Samsung and Intel SSDs.

ry
2017-01-10 20:18

ry
2017-01-10 20:18

ry
2017-01-10 20:18
if I understand the situation we're draining the Canadian supply of Intel SSDs.

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:20
@ry Something that's never made sense to me, why does CI run slower than the same tests on my laptop? It sounds like we are throwing some serious hardware at it... is it just resource contention?

ry
2017-01-10 20:21
are you running it from a completely new instance? when I compared our slices to cbf's laptop in Amsterdam they were approximately equal. the major difference is there is no caching in CI (by design)

ry
2017-01-10 20:22
so - I don't know. From a CPU and RAM standpoint we should be approximately equal. I can look up the exact specs if you would like

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:22
I am just looking at the timestamps on the output of the unit tests. I would think by the time the unit test code is actually spun up, caching of things like docker images should not be a problem.

ry
2017-01-10 20:23
it is a puzzle and, tbh, a bit of a religious issue for me. it's hard to beat the "run the unit tests" drum if it's slower and more flaky in CI

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:23
Not like knowing the exact specs is going to change anything, I just would normally expect a server class machine to shred my laptop in terms of compile times etc.

ry
2017-01-10 20:24
when we tested this, I set up a VM with much more CPU and RAM and it didn't go faster.

ry
2017-01-10 20:25
so, I don't know. Are you coming to SF in a few weeks? I'm willing to sit down and work on this to understand it

ghaskins
2017-01-10 20:25
i can say anecdotally that the CI VMs seem to be substantially slower that certain tasks than local builds: for instance, vagrant builds of the baseimage

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:25
No SF for me, but would be happy to work with you if there's some way I can be helpful

ghaskins
2017-01-10 20:26

ghaskins
2017-01-10 20:26

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:28
@ry Looking at https://jenkins.hyperledger.org/job/fabric-verify-x86_64/4952/console it's made it past chaincode

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:28
Looks like maybe it was a transient performance problem after all, but will have to see how the other builds turn out

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:35
As an example performance comparison, after running a `make clean` locally, running `make unit-test` I see: ``` unit-tests_1 | ok http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode 276.892s coverage: 60.5% of statements ``` Compared to the CI run ``` 20:21:22 [33munit-tests_1 |[0m ok http://github.com/hyperledger/fabric/core/chaincode 1142.413s coverage: 60.5% of statements ```

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:43
And, `make clean && time make unit-test` takes 17 minutes of real time on my laptop, comparing to the same steps in the CI logs which in 4952 took 57 minutes

cbf
2017-01-10 20:45
yeah, I have been saying this for weeks... combination of things contribute to slownesd

jyellick
2017-01-10 20:51
Personally, even 17 minutes locally is far too long for unit tests. Would love to see this drop down by an order of magnitude (Which would undoubtedly help CI as well). For starters I think we could run the individual package tests in parallel. Even on a relatively weak machine, I imagine at least 2 or 3 could run in parallel, with many more for a stronger one.

ry
2017-01-10 21:22
I think the next step is to see how this compares to p and z, and see if they're also slower than your laptops

ghaskins
2017-01-10 21:29
I am of the opinion that we would be well served to tier the testing with the first tier under 5 minutes as a goal

ghaskins
2017-01-10 21:29
quick/dirty UTs

ghaskins
2017-01-10 21:29
encourage frequent exercise, etc

ghaskins
2017-01-10 21:30
and then move more heavy weight stuff to subsequent tiers

ghaskins
2017-01-10 21:30
looks at chaincode UT

harrijk
2017-01-20 22:14
a set for fabric, fabric-ca, and fabric-baseimage right now

harrijk
2017-01-20 22:15

2017-01-20 22:15

2017-01-27 22:22

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:24
these commits are good go in v1.0-alpha-preview images

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:34
@ghaskins could you please push images of above commits to HL dockerhub today

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:35
i think that would have to go through the CR process

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:35
I dont have direct access to dockerhub any more

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:36
jenkins pushes them out

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:39
CI don't have a job to publish images based on specific commit number...

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:40
understood, nor would I advise that

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:40
if I were going to do this, id probably do something like: in each project, create a v1.0-alpha-preview branch

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:41
create a release commit with VERSION=v1.0-alpha-preview1 IS_RELEASE=true, push that to gerrit

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:41
create a follow up VERSION=v1.0-alpha-preview2 IS_RELEASE=false

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:41
and tag the first

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:41
thats the right way to do it

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:41
yes agree

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:43
i have a suggestion

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:43
rather than cut a release (because, imo, we arent ready)

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:44
just do something like create a GH org ("hackfest-sf-feb2017") and checkout the three trees there

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:44
sorry, fork

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:45
that might be far more flexible and appropriate for the state of the code

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:47
that's a better way. will create repos as mentioned above with above commits

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:47
then will create a job to build these commits

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:48
cool...that will be way easier if you have to add another patch or something

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:48
wait, are you planning on pushing those images?

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:48
I would suggest just having people pull from the org

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:49
if the goal were only to make jenkins see the trees, you could just use a refspec to the current repos

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:49
I would not suggest putting anything on dockerhub under "hyperledger/fabric" that hasnt gone through the release process I described above

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:50
if that is really the goal, i suggest doing the real release process

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:50
but again, i discourage that from what I have seen

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:50
we are planning to keep them in hyperledger

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:51
I wouldnt advise that, but again, if that is the intent, it should flow through the release process so we retain the tags, etc

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:51
and also, perhaps more importantly, to be sure enough maintainers are signing off on it

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:53
and all of this is not even considering the fact that we still are not ready to support a binary deployment model

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:53
(FAB-678, etc)

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:54
close, but not quite there

ramesh
2017-01-27 22:58
Yes I see your point but on latest commits end-to-end program and multichannel tests are not working

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:59
right, but you can branch from whereever you like

ghaskins
2017-01-27 22:59
so what I am suggesting is, create a branch in each repo with a logical, unified name, and from the commit sha you wanted

ghaskins
2017-01-27 23:00
then, we will submit release CRs on top of that branch, over the shas you want, that form the release

ghaskins
2017-01-27 23:00
finally, the CI process will produce the artifacts for publication

ghaskins

@cbf @garisingh @muralisr @binhn any comments here?
